column2: The rising curve of crime in the suburbs became more than an abstraction to one Bergen County couple recently when they came home to find some of their bureau drawers rifled and an easily portable chest of the silverware received as a wedding gift years ago missing.
TOKYO, Oct. 15--Japan has selected the McDonnell-Douglas F-15 as its next mainstay fighter for its Self-Defense Forces.
When shoppers at supermarkets across the country ask store clerks to direct them to the soup section, frequently all thy bother to say is, "Where do you keep Campbell's?"

ALBANY, Oct. 15--With Election Day little more than two weeks away, Senator James L. Buckley is cramming as many appearances as time will allow from dawn to midnight, upstate and downstate, into a hard campaign for re-election.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 15--President Ford has apparently modified the Administration's policy on Middle East negotiations and brought it closer to that favored by Israel.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 15 (UPI)--The pound closed substantially higher on European money markets today, after the Bank of England raised borrowing rates for currency speculators. The dollar also closed on a higher trend.
BUFFALO, Oct. 15 (UPI)--Lou Saban resigned today as head coach of the National Football League Buffalo Bills and Jim Ringo, an assistant whom Saban hired in 1972, was named to replace him.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 15--A confidential World Bank study of the Venezuelan economy presents a very favorable assessment of this oil-producing nation but suggests that the Government must adopt effective tax reforms and encourage additional public savings if growth is to be steady over the 1976-80 period.

In temporarily depriving the United Federation of Teachers of its automatic dues check-off privilege, the Public Employment Relations Board has merely imposed the penalty mandated by law. It is unquestionably the most effective response to illegal strikes. It is not, as union president Albert Shanker charges, a "vengeful" act nor an attempt, as he suggests, to make of the teachers "the scapegoat" for other municipal workers.

President Ford, on the campaign trail, said this week that despite the "pause" that has lifted the unemployment rate and depressed the stock market, he doesn't see "any need for change in our economic policy."
The new director of New Jersey Common Cause, Randy Huwa, says the so-called sunset bills in the State Legislature are among the top priorities of support by the public-affairs lobby.

Expressing irritation and impatience, the Emergency Financial Control Board told Mayor Beame yesterday that it could not accept any budget submissions from the New York City hospital system without a "restructuring of management" at the Health and Hospitals Corporation-- including the possible replacement of Dr. L.S. Holloman, the corporation president.

Senators Walter F. Mondale and Robert J. Dole met last night in a sporadically acrimonious debate, the first ever between vice-Presidential nominees, and argued whether Republican fiscal prudence or Democratic social programs would best serve the nation's economy.
BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP)--Jean Ratelle scored on a power play and set up two goals tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 5-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

About the art of Andrew Wyeth, everyone seems to have made up his mind--often, it seems, quite independently of any first-hand experience of the artist's work or any serious reflection upon it--so perhaps all that a critic need do is announce to the world that a mammoth exhibition of Mr. Wyeth's paintings and drawings opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and let it go at that.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Oct. 16 --Thailand's military junta has begun a nationwide roundup of leftist writers, professors and intellectuals under a new directive allowing detention of suspected Communists for up to 30 days with no bail and no charges.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla.--The magic number now is 30. It took a long time --12 long years in fact--for this 30 to turn up.

Saul Kaplan, an attorney and former chief counsel to the New York State Democratic Party and the legislative leadership died Thursday at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami, Fla. He was 66 years old and lived in Bay Harbor Island, Fla. since his retirement in 1965.
HACKENSACK, Oct. 15--Fields, woodwooded areas, towns and estates in Bergen County are fast becoming "office landscapes."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to phase out all nonessential uses of fluorocarbon propellants in spray cans because of the danger they pose to the Earth's protective ozone layer.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15--Syrian tanks and infantry increased their pressure today on the Palestinian stronghold of Aleih, east of here, but though the fighting was fierce, they gained little ground.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (UPI)-- Jimmy Carter says he will send his wife on diplomatic missions and use her and his sons as aides in domestic affairs if he is elected President.

The sudden dismissal of Arthur R. Taylor as president of CBS Inc. last Wednesday was generally considered to have been unrelated to the poor showing of the television network in the ratings so far this season.

TOKYO, Oct. 15--The Justice Minister of Japan said today in an interim report on the Lockheed bribery scandal that 14 members of Parliament who received money originating from the corporation had escaped prosecution.
WHITE PLAINS--Ellen Altman was afraid to sit on a chair. So she perched on the living room steps of her splitlevel house in White Plains.

The only woman in the West German Cabinet, Health Minister Katharina Focke, announced her resignation yesterday after four years. She had served earlier in the government of Willy Brandt and will retain her seat in Parliament. Mrs. Focke, who left Germany with her anti-Nazi family in World War II, studied in 1951-52 at the University of Oklahoma and has a Ph.D. in philology.

The Communications Satellite Corporation, which derives most of its revenues from leasing channels on a worldwide communications satellite system, yesterday reported declines of 35.6 percent in third quarter income and 18.5 percent for the first nine months.

Chris Chambliss supplied the lightning on the first pitch in the last of the ninth in the final game of the American League championship series. The Yankees won the game and their first American League pennant in 12 years. So the stadium exploded and a warm feeling of pride spread through the night to the rest of the city.

Testimony ended yesterday in the four-day, multimillion-dollar court battle between Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight champion, and a fight referee, Anthony Perez. The trial in United States District Court is expected to go to the jury of four women and two men on Monday after each side makes a summation and the judge issues instructions on the law to the jurors.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Oct. 16 --Thailand's military junta has begun a nationwide roundup of leftist writers, professors and intellectuals under a new directive allowing detention of suspected Communists for up to 30 days with no bail and no charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--The vice president in charge of real estate for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has made an invention for the company in a distinctly different field. Samuel H. Hellenbrand was granted a patent this week for what is called a heart detective.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Oct. 15--Gay 90's nostalgia has swept through furniture collections introduced this week at the Southern Furniture Market here. And some of the thousands of manufacturers and store buyers gathered for the semiannual showings view the weighty results--the rolltop desks and moustache shavings stands, the brass beds, fainting couches and player pianos --as the biggst furniture fad to hit since Mediterranean flooded the market in the late 1960's.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)--Soybean futures prices fell heavily on the Chicago Board of Trade today and strongly influenced lower prices in nearly all other commodities on the floor.

KRANJ, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15--A Yugoslav district judge, arrested last May in his courtroom as the result of his advocacy of civil rights, was convicted today of treason and other crimes and sentenced to six years imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--The White House today ordered Clarence M. Kelley the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to abandon a proposed speech that was sharply critical of recent news coverage of his agency.

Peggy Lee's annual appearances in the Empire Room of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel are always somewhat of an adventure. There have been times when her performances there have been brilliant and others, such as the last two years, when, because of material, orchestrations or battles with the sound system, she has been surprisingly ineffective.
LOS ANGELES. OCT. 15--A cooler economy has taken some of the steam out of what a few months ago had promised to be a blistering recovery for the nation's mobile home industry.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., OCT. 14--A visitor stopped a blearly-eyed Walt Michaels in the corridor of the New York Jets training facility at Hofstra and tried to congratulate him on the way he has turned around the Jet defense in the last three weeks. Michaels, however, wasn't ready to take any laurels just yet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)--The Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Federal Housing Administration announced today that the maximum allowable interest rate on F.H.A.-H.U.D. single-family home loans had been dropped to 8 percent.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15--Out here in Middle America along the banks of the Ohio River, the uncertainties of life and even of Presidential politics were yielding today to some sure things: Johnny Bench's throwing arm, Joe Morgan's ability to steal bases, George Fosters booming bat and the widespread notion that the Cincinnati Reds will train all these weapons on the New York Yankees in the World Series, which opens here tomorrow at Riverfront Stadium.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct.15--Prime Minister John Vorster had extended discussions today with Roelof W. Botha South Africa's Ambassador to the United States, apparently to decide whether South Africa should attend a conference on South-West Africa that Secretary a State Henry A. Kissinger has proposed as the means of resolving the impass on the future of the territory, also known as Namibia.

BROADSTAIRS, England, Oct. 15 (AP) --William George Heath, the father of the former Conservative Prime Minister, Edward Heath, died today at his home at Broadstairs, 75 miles southeast of London. He was 88 years old five days ago.

Proud and calculating, the owners and breeders of thoroughbred competitors convened Thursday night at the Lithuanian hall in Maspeth, Queens, for the great futurity race today--exactly 308.483 miles from Charlottesville, Va., to Joe LaRocca's loft, as the pigeon flies.

The False Alarm Deterrent Corporation, East Bridgewater, Mass., received a patent this week for what its corporate name implies. The method and apparatus have been demonstrated for Massachusetts public officials.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 14--A leading group of private and Government economists today dismissed fears that the nation's economic recovery might be running out of steam. Instead, they forecast that steady economic growth would resume toward the end of the year and continue throughout 1977 and into 1978

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--A preliminary report by the General Tire and Rubber Company's special review com mittee indicates it has found many of the same questionable and illegal practices with which the Securities and Exchange Commission charged it last spring.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15--This Yankee team never has been in a World Series, but that doesn't mean the players will act as if they were a bunch of rookies just happy to have the chance to watch the big bad Reds play in person. Even if they wanted to behave like that, Billy Martin wouldn't let them.

Assistant Chief Anthony V. Bouza, one of the highest ranking and most controversial commanders in the New York Police Department, said yesterday that the force could be trimmed 10 percent more without affecting crime control or other services.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--Americans have received more than two and a half million doses of flu vaccine in the last two weeks, a Federal agency reported today, and there has been "no evidence whatever" that the vaccinations are causing deaths.
The state's new antiloitering law, which was designed to combat street prostitution, was declared unconstitutionally vague yesterday by a Manhattan Criminal Court judge.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation filed an antitrust suit yesterday against 29 uranium producers, charging price fixing and curtailment of supply.

HAVANA, Oct. 15--Prime Minister Fidel Castro said today that he would renounce Cuba's 1973 antihijacking agreement with the United States because of what he described as American complicity in the crash of a sabotaged Cuban airliner off Barbados last week.
Members of the musicians' union, who have been on strike against the New York City Opera, ratified a new agreement yesterday, opening the way for a resumption of performances Tuesday night.

A joyous epilogue to the dramatic last-inning Yankee pennant victory over Kansas City erupted Thursday night outside Yankee Stadium and went on until after 1 A.M. yesterday, with strangers embracing, pounding one another on the back and shoulders, offering one another drinks out of bottles.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14--When this city resumes its flu immunization program Monday, Mrs. James Carlson might not be in the line for her shot.

DENVER, Oct. 15--The land subdivision industry, estimated to control enough acreage to house from 45 million to 60 million people, has "degenerated into an updated version of the old snake oil racket," a 550-page report just released by a nonprofit research group says.

PEKING, Saturday, Oct. 16--Throngs in the supposed radical bastion of Shanghai yesterday reportedly celebrated the down fall of the widow of Mao Tse-tong and three other radicals by marching through the streets, plastering downtown buildings with posters and demonstrating in front of municipal headquarters.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 15--Daniel P. Moynihan carried his campaign for the United States Senate to four upstate New York cities today including Syracuse where he ran into some predictably bumpy roads in the area where the state's Conservative Party got its start.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 15--President Ford said here today that Jimmy Carter was a political quick-change artist who would harm farmers by using their produce as a diplomatic weapon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)--A lawyer for 10 present and retired members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters says he has filed a class-action suit accusing three teamsters' union pension funds of cheating their members out of pensions.

Lawrence Peirez, an international vice president of B'nai B'rith and chairman of the national civil rights committee of that organization's Anti-Defamation League, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 61 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

The Universal Leaf Tobacco Company said it had filed a complaint in the United States Federal District Court in Richmond seeking an injunction against the Congoleum Corporation's acquiring any Universal shares or attempting to acquire control of Universal.

A joyous epilogue to the dramatic last-inning Yankee pennant victory over Kansas City erupted Thursday night outside Yankee Stadium and went on until after 1 A.M. yesterday, with strangers embracing, pounding one another on the back and shoulders, offering one another drinks out of bottles.

James V. Napoli Sr., who headed the largest gambling operation in the country, with 2,000 employees in the metropolitan area and an operation estimated at $120 million to $150 million a year, was sentenced yesterday to five years in jail and a $20,000 fine. It was the maximum penalty under the law.

Although the overall fiscal condition of the State of New York is better than that of the city, Albany could be in serious trouble unless Governor Carey takes prompt steps to head off a budget deficit that threatens to grow to more than $200 million by the end of the fiscal year six months from now.

The City of New York and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday called in Michael I. Sovern, dean of the Columbia University Law School and a veteran labor mediator, to help resolve a contract dispute that has resulted in several weeks of street demonstrations by off-duty policemen.

Jimmy Carter said yesterday that Felix G. Rohatyn's plan to stretch out the long-term debt of New York City merits "serious consideration," and he criticized President Ford for what he described as Mr. Ford's "cavalier rejection" of the refinancing proposal.

HARTFORD, Oct. 15--A United States District Court judge declared today that Federal prosecutors in Connecticut had been using their right to peremptory jury challenges too frequently on blacks, keeping them from serving on criminal juries, and he moved to halt the practice.

OSLO, Oct. 15--The Nobel Committee of the Norwegian Parliament decided today not to award a Nobel Peace Prize The decision by the five-member committee followed the nomination of more than 50 persons and organizations for the award. The last time the committee failed to agree on a prize was in 1972.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, has declined to begin an inquiry into whether President Ford, as a Congressman in 1972, sought to block an investigation of Watergate by a committee of the House of Representatives at the behest of the Nixon White House.
New York is not yet out of the red by a long shot. Tough times and painful new belt-tightening still lie ahead. Bankruptcy remains an ominous possibility.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 15--John Kani and Winston Ntshona, two black actors who won Tony awards on Broadway last year, will be brought to trial in connection with their performances last week in the prize-winning play, "Sizwe Banzi is Dead," Kaiser Matanzima, chief minister of the Transkei, said tonight.

Morris A. Zeldin, a pioneer in the Zionist movement here 60 years ago and one of the organizers ofthe United Jewish Appeal of New York 37 years ago, died Thursday in Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 3885 Darby Lane, Seaford, L.I.

PATERSON, Oct. 15--Mayors and business leaders of 22 municipalities surrounding this Passaic County city were told today that they had to band together on a regional basis--with Paterson as the hub--to solve common problems if their communities were to survive and prosper.

A miniature ultrasonic thickness measuring instrument, which was patented this week for Krauthamer-Branson Inc. of Stratford, Conn., is described as exhibiting improved stability and calibration adaptability.
DETROIT, Oct. 15--Jimmy Carter denounced Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford today, charging them with failure to reverse the country's rising crime rate.
The stock market closed slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--Charles F. Ruff, the Watergate special prosecutor, has declined to begin an inquiry into whether President Ford, as a Congressman in 1972, sought to block an investigation of Watergate by a committee of the House of Representatives at the behest of the Nixon White House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--The White House today ordered Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to abandon a proposed speech that was sharply critical of recent news coverage of his agency.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16 Although they lost their leading ground gainer late in the third quarter, the Colgate Red Raiders scored two touchdowns by Bruce Malverty in the final 12 minutes and defeated Princeton, 17-7, at Palmer Stadium today. The victory was Colgate's fifth straight this season.

Construction of new apartment houses in New York City is at the lowest level since 1932, the depth of the depression, and existing units available for rental purposes are steadily deteriorating. In consequence, it is urgent that the New York State Legislature, when it convenes in January, adopt a fresh comprehensive approach toward housing in the Metropolitan area.

Brigid Shanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Michael Shanley of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help to James Raymond Lamb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond James Lamb of Ridgewood, N.J.

Tank tests. Design secrets. Boats under wraps. It's not exactly trick-ortreat, but the season for 12-Meter racing is in the wind. And the effects of rule changes and new methods of tank testing are beginning to surface.

ANN ARBOR, Mich. The fall of Chiang Ching and her three Shanghai associates removes the most poisonous elements in Peking affecting SinoAmerican relations. This does not guarantee a quick agreement on normalization and the question of Taiwan, but it removes the primary obstacle to Chinese compromise.
BREST, France, Oct. 16 (Reuters) Huge oil slicks gushing from the sunken East German tanker Boehlen today threatened more than 12 miles of Brittany's coastline, French authorities said.

ATHENS The great lawmaker of ancient Greece, Solon, insisted that "he shall be disfranchised who, in time of faction, takes neither side." The reason for insisting on this stern responsibility was the wise Athenian's recognition that no democracy could function with effect unless each individual voter exercised his duty to express a choice. Only thus could ,public opinion be properly assessed.

LONDON Swinburne called Christopher Marlowe "the father of English tragedy," a status that presumably explains why he, and not Shakespeare, was the au thor chosen to baptize the most important auditorium in the new National Theater complex and potentially the most exciting one the nation itself possesses. Not all the Olivier Theater's gadgetry is yet working. Scenery cannot be whisked into the flies, or plunged into the basement, at the shove of a button.

I feel like the snake in the Garden of Eden, like Scrooge at Christmastime, maybe like King Canute ordering the sea to roll back. About a week ago I went to see "Porgy and Bess," which in its revival by the Houston Grand Opera at the Uris Theater has been universally received as the greatest thing since "Le Nozze di Figaro."

Therese Irene Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Murphy of Potsdam, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to John Carver Burditt, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederic Burditt, of Bedford Hills, N.Y.
Floral Park scored in every quarter yesterday, defeating Locust Valley in the process, 32-14, in what may prove to be the decisive game in the Nassau Conference VII race.

LONDON, Oct. 16-The British Government agreed today to postpone the formal opening of the forthcoming Geneva conference on Rhodesia, whose purpose is to form an interim biracial Rhodesian government that will lead to rule by the black majority in the southern African country.

NASSAU Republicans are priately conceding that the perjury conviction of a Hempstead Town official who allegedly pressured municipal employees to contribute to the Republican Party is only the tip of the iceberg.

The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington and its music director, Antal Dorati, must have had the feeling that the Big Apple was in serious need of some new music. That, at least, might explain their bringing three new pieces to play in their concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday night.

Commodores in the American merchant marine, especially with the disappearance of United States-flag passenger shipping on the East Coast, are getting scarcer than pearls in an oyster. And one of them, Capt. Leroy J. Alexanderson of United ...

After spending parts of two years as a fund-raising salesman, Mike Battle is able to spend a good part of this year as the starting fullback at Beach Channel High, the newest member of the Public Schools Athletic League.

OUR children are the future of our nation. What our children become, so becomes our nation. It is plain common sense to give our children the best education possible so that they can develop into productive responsible citizens contributing economically, socially and politically to our democratic society.
CHICAGO On his second day on the job Derick January Daniels, the new president of Playboy Enterprises, Inc., did something that few other men in his position would have contemplated. He got married.

HONG KONG It is difficult to find many pessimists these days in the financial and business community of this throbbing city, which is both a barometer of economic activity in the industrialized world and the main door for China's commercial dealings with the west.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 16 This Arkansas-Oklahoma border city on the Arkansas River has become the focal point for the planning of a major attack on "natural pollution."

The engagement of Hester Harrington Eggert to Charles D. Weeden has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Robinson Eggert Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Seawall, Me., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Weeden of Oakland, Calif. A spring wedding is planned.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 16 Lawrenceville held its Centennial Game today in its 100th year of football, and Andover proved to be a cooperative guest in dropping a 16-14 decision. A bad snap from the Andover center in the fourth quarter gave Lawrenceville a two-point safety that provided the winning margin.

Mr. and Mrs. Sheffield J. Halsey of Ossining, N.Y., and Sea Island, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Louise Halsey, to George R. Stiteler, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H.H. Stiteler of Broomall, Pa. The couple plan to be married in December.

There seems little doubt that when an elderly person with a heart condition goes to a clinic and receives a flu shot, he or she is under some degree of physical and mental stress that might not otherwise exist. But, while at least 14 of the sick and elderly died last week soon after being immunized in the national flu vaccination program, the implications of the added stress are unclear.

MUNICH Ingmar Bergman has quietly decided to settle in Munich. The film director says that the theme that obsessed him in the past the quest for God amid despair and emptiness has disappeared, and he yearns to make films about ordinary people and realistic, straightforward relationships. He says he will never work in Sweden again.
Adam Smith is generally hailed as the father of modern economics, and Milton Friedman as his most distinguished spiritual son.

New York State's Public Employment Relations Board handed down a stiff penalty last week for last fall's illegal strike by New York City teachers. At the same time, however, it expressed concern that the law did not provide a "standard of evenhandedness" in the imposition of loss of dues checkoff.
IT'S a bit difficult to visualize Bitsy Gaeta as a big bully from Bloomfield, but that's what she says she used to be, all four feet, 11 inches and 100 pounds of her.

Long Branch stopped Asbury Park's high-powered offense yesterday and emerged from the battle of unbeaten teams with a 22-0 victory in Long Branch. Tim Wilson paced the Long Branch attack by running 2 yards for one touchdown and passing for two others. He hit Monte Robinson for 10 yards and Merlin Austin for 22 yards. Asbury Park finished with only 50 rushing yards.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 They kept asking Sparky Anderson, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, why he and his players seemed so cool after winning the first game of the World Series something they had failed to do in their three previous Series since 1970.
I am responding to Marion Lane Rogers's excellent article of Sept. 12 on this page entitled "Put the Players in Charge."

They came to Roosevelt Auditorium at 100 East 17th Street yesterday afternoon about 300 men and women, long-time Socialists and for three hours they heard tributes paid to the memory of Eugene V. Debs and Meyer London, founders of the Socialist Party.

WE finally had the closing on our house three weeks after moving. Although the allocation for the mortgage somehow came to $2,500 less than the amount originally agreed upon, I was again assured that "everything will probably he all right." We managed the closing even though the new roof was leaking and green plants were pushing up through the asphalt of the driveway.
Sarah Hastings Fleming and William Stirling Tomkins were married at noon yesterday in St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., by the Rev. John Greely.
"Fanfarita," as this column noted eight years ago, is not the name of somebody's little Mexican granddaughter. It is the title of a short, snappy Spanish-tinted pas de trois by Gerald Arpino.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 16 It was as if the Islanders were looking at a mirror image of themselves. They were held to a 4-4 tie tonight by the Cleveland Barons, a team few people out of hockey's inner sanctum ever heard of.

The defending champion, Suffern, took its second straight defeat in Rockland public-school football yesterday, losing to Ramapo, 13-12. Meanwhile, Nyack tightened its hold on first place with a 20-3 victory over Pearl River.

Nancy Ann Hussey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hussey of Lloyd Flarbor, Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday morning to Raymond G. Schuville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schuville of Farrell, Pa.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 16 Windshield Wiper, the 3-year-old son of Meadow Skipper who has been chasing Keystone Ore all year, finally caught him today and passed him about 50 yards from the wire to capture the $44,300 James B. Dancer Memorial Pace.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 16 Thailand's military junta said tonight that it was holding at least 200 leftist leaders, including a number of leading intellectuals, writers and politicians.

A magazine called Money was on the telephone. It spoke in a human voice. It requested an interview to enlighten the nation about how I handled my own particular money. Joseph Heller, Mike Nichols and Dr. Joyce Brothers had granted similar interviews, which I read with profound interest.

Valentin Hirsu, who recently arrived in New York from his native Rumania and became a new member of the Philharmonic's cello section this season, made his solo debut last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program consisted of four sonatas, by Brahms (Op. 38), Britten (Op. 65), Beethoven (Op. 69) and Debussy.

Linda Ann Detweiler, assistant to the associate publisher of The National Review a weekly newspaper, was married yesterday afternoon to David Kilgour Black, a member of the National Players Repertory Company. Dom Gregory Floyd performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Thomas Mores Roman Catholic Church.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Oct. 16 Ken Norton has been guaranteed a minimum of $1.1 million to fight George Foreman later this year, Don King, the boxing promoter, announced today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) Mickey Johnson scored 21 points and Norm Van Lier added 18 in sparking the Chicago Bulls to a 96-93 preseason victory over the New York Nets tonight.

When public clamor for environmental reform reached a crescendo a half dozen years ago, smoking factories became a symbol of air pollution, and industry's horrific discharge pipes a conspicuous culprit in water pollution. Industry, along with automobiles and municipal sewage, was a prime target of ensuing legislation, notably the Clean Air Act of 1970 and the Water Pollution Control Act of 1972.

Gerald Ford's personal and political Finances during the latter days of his Congressional career have been declared faultless after an investigation by the Watergate special prosecutor, thus relieving Mr. Ford of a campaign burden he could not dispel himself. Nevertheless, in a week when morality and the quality of leadership were the subjects that dominated political discussion, the President remained largely on the defensive.

HOUSTON, Oct. 16-Once upon a time in a faraway Islamic kingdom these lived a middle-aged prince whose 18-year-old daughter yearned to taste fruit long forbidden to females of the realm--namely, a college education.

The North American Soccer League will play more regular-season games next year, enlarge its playoffs, import top referees and have rosters of 16 players, six of whom must be American or Canadian citizens.

It's refreshing to hear a young pianist present a debut recital of the sort given by Elaine Greenfield last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. Not only was the choice of music well-balanced and unhackneyed, but each piece was admirably tailored to the pianist's capabilities and temperament.

Reading these two latest contributions to the pile of publications on the Enlightenment, I was irresistibly reminded of Voltaire's gloomy response to the books that were inundating his desk. The writer who seeks originality, he thought, was compelled to be eccentric; the writer who wishes to avoid eccentricity is bound to be un- ...

CINCINNATI, OCT. 16 Jimmy Carter, annoyed by the President's portrayal of him as an irresponsible, big-spending reformer, countered today by releasing the contents of a telegram in which he had asked Mr. Ford to stop making "misleading and erroneous statements" to the American people.
Two place-kickers from Texas set colegiate fild-goal records in football games 300 miles apart yesterday.

A lovely little cameo here in its intention and execution. In focus is one family on a spring night, a special night, when the moon's slender fingers of light "make patches of white snow on the driveway" and reveals the doings and thoughts of everyone. Mother is doing the dishes, thinkiirg of father who is leading the newspaper by moonlight on the porch.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 16 C.W. Post, ranked first in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Diviion III poll and in the Lambent Bowl, ruined the homecoming of the United States Merchant Marine Academy here today by handing the Mariners a 16-0 defeat before a crowd of 5,700.
CAIRO, Oct. 16 Ramses II, the Pharaoh whose mummy is now in Paris for treatment of a fungus, was particular during his lifetime over how his public perceived him, a conference here has been told.

Letitia Baldrige recails that one Washington hostess was so determined to carry out etiquette rules that call for alternating men and women at a dinner table that she was once seated between an ambassador with halitosis and a 14-year-old boy.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 16-In the face of recent reports of liberalized morals in Utah, more than 9,000 people nearly filled the Salt Palace Arena this morning for a well-publicized rally against pornography.

Dan H. Laurence, literary adviser to the George Bernard Shaw estate, and for the last 17 years editor of Shaw's "Collected Letters," has resigned both positions after what he termed "unresolvable differences" with the estate and Shaw's literary agents.

The central problem for choreographers maturing in the 1960's was learning how to move without slavishly imitating their predecessors. For some modern dancers it meant almost the total abnegation of movement. Pedro Sanjuan, Spanish composer and conductor who founded the Havana Philharmonic, died yesterday in Washington. He would have been 90 years old on Nov. 15.
The credit markets seemed to have second thoughts about the near-term outlook for interest rates yesterday and the case for a continued decline in rates became less convincing.
Some time ago in this column I deplored the use of "harvest" to describe the killing of game by hunters.
Ellen Donna Cooperman went to court the other day in an effort to change her name to Cooperperson. She lost.

The Internal Revenue Service is investigating the financial affairs of Ira Duchan, who retired suddenly on Saturday from his post as New York City Real Estate Commissioner, persons close to Mr. Duchan said yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct.18 For four years, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez, has campaigned tirelessly for a "new world economic order," hoping to win either the Nobel Peace Prize or the Secretary Generalship of the United Nations before his Presidential term ends Dec. 1.

PHOENIX, Oct. 18 Jury selection for the trial of the accused slayer of Don Bolles, an investigative reporter for The Arizona Republic, began today behind closed doors and under tight security in a Phoenix courtroom.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 18-Ashar Yadlin, Governor-designate of the Bank of Israel, was detained by police today after an intensive investigation into allegations that he made illicit profits in kickbacks through a series of real estate transactions by the Labor Federation's disability fund, which he headed.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 18 Prime Minister John Vorster made it clear today that his Government would continue to exclude blacks from participation in the mainstream of South Africa's political life, but he pledged that discriminatory measures that served no purpose would be scrapped.

Staff members of the New York State Public Service Commission, in an unusually critical review of a rate increase sought by Consolidated Edison, recommended yesterday that all but $11.4 million of the $249.8 million annual increase sought by the utility be denied.

Sparky Anderson, who has managed 1,264 Cincinnati Reds games under "ordinary" baseball rules, has now managed two using the designated hitter and his opinion about that rule has firmed up. Before trying it, he considered it "terrible"; after the first game of the World Series, he upgraded that to "it stinks"; now he considers it moronic."

The Si-Yo Music Society's sixth annual chamber music series got under way Sunday afternoon at Pace University's Schimmel Center for the Arts. Although the four musicians participating in the concert do not constitute a regularly performing quartet, their readings left little to be desired in terms of ensemble rapport and perceptive insights on the music at hand.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has begun a drive in Alabama to get the last known surviving "Scottsboro boy" pardoned from a 1946 parole violation.

The protection of the environment is a major concern for many citizens and for the nation's future. Despite its importance, neither Presidential candidate has devoted much attention to the issue. In the light of their records and their public statements, President Ford and Governor Carter stand as almost polar opposites in the environmental field.

Most rough executions of television commercials are practically as effective for copy testing as finished spots, a business school professor told a large assembly of advertising researchers yesterday.

BONN, Oct. 18 Pressures eased in many European currency markets today following West Germany's surprise upward revaluation of the mark against six other European currencies last night. However, the move did little to relieve the stress upon the currencies of Germany's most important European trading partners the British pound, the French franc and the Italian lira.
James M. Osborn, a Yale University English scholar and literary detective, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 70 years old and a resident of New Haven.

Nine busloads of middle-class residents from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx went to City Hall yesterday to protest before the Site Selection Board against the opening of Offtrack Betting Corporation parlors in their respective neighborhoods.

CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo., Oct. 18 Senator Robert J. Dote, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, has spent the last three days stumping through his native Midwest in an attempt to repair sagging Republican fences.

The Beame administration is actively seeking a replacement for Dr. John L.S. Holloman, the beleaguered president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, but it has been turned down by three of the persons approached, officials said yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, Oct 18 (Reuters) Nearly 700 blacks in the township of Soweto marched last night on a municipal depot, forced their way past its guards and commandeered a dozen trucks and a water tanker and drove the vehicles through fences and into walls, according to police.

Moses Malone, trying to survive in the world of professional basketball ever since he bypassed college in 1974 to sign with the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association, was traded yesterday by the Portland Trail Blazers to the Buffalo Braves.

New York City's Deputy Mayor for inance, John C. Burton, took strong exception yesterday to a publicized, but unreleased, draft report of the Pension Task Force of the House subcommittee on labor standards that was highly critical of the investment practices of New York pension systems.

HONG KONG, Oct. 18 The effort to undercut China's leftists continued to spread today with reports of wall posters attacking lesser officials in Shanghai for their ties to Chiang Ching, Mao Tse-tung's widow, and three other senior leaders reportedly arrested 10 days ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A Cuban exile under arrest in Trinidad has admitted planting a bomb that caused a Cuban airliner to crash off Barbados on Oct. 6, killing 73 persons, according to reports reaching Government officials here today.

The story of Joan Little, the young black prisoner in North Carolina who was accused and acquitted of murdering her white jailer last year, is a potentially treacherous subject for dramatization. On stage it could easily be turned into a political diatribe, a platform for special pleading, or a courtroom melodrama.

The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that his agency would "consider shortly" raising the 50-cent fare by 10 or 15 cents because of a loss of revenues that had been expected.

Senator James L. Buckley of New York called yesterday far the resignation of Gen. George S. Brown, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who had been quoted in an interview as suggesting that Israel was a military burden for the United States.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (UPI) Eugene McCarthy, an independent candidate for the Presidency, said today that he would have a good chance to be elected if he were allowed to take part in the final debate Friday night.

When William N. Lipscomb Jr. was a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, he heard a professor propose a theory of chemical bonding in certain boron compounds. Something about the theory did not seem right, and he set out to prove his professor wrong. In so doing, he won the 1976 Nobel Prize in chemistry.
Why is it that a sacrifice, even a perfectly innocuous one, so often succeeds dramatically?
The first issue of The Wilson Quarterly, which calls itself "a national review of ideas and information," was published yesterday in Washington.

The demand of the Emergency Financial Control Board for a "restructuring" of the deficit-ridden Health and Hospitals Corporations touches only one aspect of a broader health care crisis which threatens to overwhelm New York City's already overburdened budget.
The New York Philharmonic will open its 135th subscription season tonight at the reconstructed Avery Fisher Hall, pending final approval this morning by orchestra players of a new contract.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-The Commerce Department made public today 59 reports from companies that said they had been asked to comply with the Arab states' boycott of Israel. None of the companies said it would refuse to comply.
Cocoa futures prices set a record high yesterday, when the December contract jumped the daily limit of 4 cents a pound to reach $1.23 90/100 on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (UPI) The United Automobile Workers resumed contract talks today with the General Motors Corporation while the Ford Motor Company, the auto industry "pattern-setter," struggled to bring its production back to pre-strike levels.

Obviously concerned over Jimmy Carter's slippage in New York State, campaign aides have begun linking the Democratic Presidential candidate to the fate of New York City and to the coattails of local Democratic candidates.

The United States Coast Guard said yesterday that the 590-foot cargo ship missing since Friday with 37 crew members in the area known as The Bermuda Triangle was now presumed to have been lost at sea in heavy winds and high seas.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 18 Wendy Yoshimura, underground traveling companion of Patricia Hearst, went on trial here today on charges of illegal possession of a machine gun, destructive devices and explosives.
Given the precipitous drop in stock prices recently, more investors than usual will be weighing tax loss carry-over factors in their trading decisions between now and the end of the year.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 18 May be Bill Arnsparger, coach of a football team with an 0-6 won-lost record and about to play the Pittsburgh Steelers, should be worrying about next Sunday. He does, after all, like his job.

Roland Hanna, Dave McKenna and Jimmy Rowles, three accomplished jazz pianists, and George Mraz, who assisted on bass, performed in the first of a series of "Heavenly Jazz" concerts Sunday at the Church of Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue an 90th Street. The results were somewhat less than celestial and the church itself was the principal culprit.

His day begins with breakfast at the cafeteria of the European Nuclear Research Center, known as CERN, in Geneva, Switzerland. It ends when he leaves his laboratory to sleep in his apartment, a ten-minute drive from the center. This is also his routine on one weekend out of two. On alternate weekends he takes off to see his wife and two young daughters in Lexington, Mass. By Monday he is back at CERN.
After a decade of shaking the pillars of American society, the feminist revolution is transforming the showcases of some of New York's most steadfastly masculine stores.

PRESERVATION HALL. By Scott Spencer. 273 pages. Knopf. $8.95. Virgil Morgan suffers from what R.D. Laing calls "an insecurity of being." He feels that he has not "earned" his pleasant existence, that he has been merely lucky. Some puberty rite, he believes, has been Omitted in his growing up, some painful confrontation with reality that would have enabled him to break through to something beyond what he calls the "confection" of his way of life.
Merrill Lynch is bullish on America, but it appears that a relatively limited number of Merrill Lynch customers are bullish on Japan at least at the firm's offices at 345 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a city's public school system may have one college preparatory school solely for boys and one solely for girls.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 18 The Republican National Committee and the A.F.L.-C.L.O. are fighting a kind of proxy war over the state's Third Congressional District that straddles the Nassau-Suffolk line, where two widely dissimilar candidates are in one of the closest Congressional races on Long Island.
Ellen Donna Cooperman went to court the other day in an effort to chance her name to Cooperperson. She lost.

BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 18 A minimum price increase of 10 percent can be expected when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Qatar in December according several oil analysts and economists gathered today at the University of Colorado for the third annual international conference on energy and development.

MOSCOW, Oct 18 (Reuters) The hazardous splashdown by two Soviet astronauts into a blizzard-swept lake was the result of chance rather than mission planning, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, indicated tonight.

Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko's new offer to discuss on-site inspection adds some credibility to Moscow's old proposal to ban all underground nuclear weapons tests. But major obstacles still hinder a comprehensive test ban. Russia's insistence that all five nuclear weapons states must agree is a dead-end street; France and China have refused even to join in the Soviet-American-British ban on atmospheric tests, which China continues to set off.

Governor Carey yesterday elevated three Justices of the State Supreme Court Frank D.O'Conor, Milton Mollen, and Joseph A. Suozzi to the court's Appellate Division, Second Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 When allegations of wrong doing are made against an incumbent President, who should investigate? Should it be the Attorney General, who has been appointed by the President? Or should it be an independent prosecutor such as those named in the Watergate affair?
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 Professional football's Rozette Rule violates Federal antitrust laws by unduly restricting the rights of players to change teams, a Federal appeals court here ruled today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 Lebanese right-wing Christian forces equipped with Israeli weapons stormed into a Moslemheld military barracks in southern Lebanon today on the second day of an offensive in the area.
The common stock of the Orion Capital Corporation, formerly the Equity Funding Corporation, began trading yesterday in the over-the-counter market.
BEST FRIEND, a play by Michael Sawyer, Directed by Marty Jacobs. Starring Barbara Baxley. At the Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street at 7.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, known as the 3M Company, reported yesterday that its net income for the third quarter gained 3.1 percent from a year ago despite substantial adverse currency changes. Sales, however, were a record for any quarter in its history, the St. Paul-based diversified producer said.
A display of togetherness was evidenced in two instances of the $55,450 Long Island Handicap, held over Belmont Park's 1 1/16-mile turf course before 13,592 chilled fans yesterday.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company reported yesterday a gain of 17.5 percent in third-quarter earnings as sales rose by 9.6 percent.
Stocks made a broad advance yesterday led by the blue-chip issues, which had been under pressure recently.
Dr. Donald Cooper has nothing but bad things to say about the "hard shell" football helmets that have been in use for years.
F. Keith Brown, a partner in the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leigy MacRae, 140 Broadway, died in Doctors Hospital Saturday after a short illness. His age 63.

PARIS, Oct. 18 The expected autumn pickup in Western European demand for steel has failed to materialize, and steelmakers are bracing for another slump.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Commerce Department made public today 59 reports from companies that said they had been asked to comply with the Arab states' boycott of Israel. None of the companies said it would refuse to comply.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 18 Teachers employed by the Nassau County Board of Cooperative Educational Services went on strike today, affecting classes for 8,500 pupils in occupational and special educational programs.

The first of four Moynihan-for-Senator television commercials the vanguard of a truncated schedule that the campaign team hopes will reach $200,000 in TV time by election day will make its debut tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico injected unexpected competition into the election of the next Secretary General today by declaring his readiness to run against the incumbent, Kurt Waldheim of Austria.

TAMPA, Fla, Oct. 18 (AP) Declaring the election "up for grabs," Jimmy Carter flew to Florida today where he embarked on what aides said would be a concentrated effort to overcome voter apathy in the remaining days of the campaign.

On Oct. 22, 1974, Dr. Samuel C.C. Ting went into the data analysis room of his experimental team at Brookhaven National Laboratory, near Upton, L.I., and posted a note on the bulletin board: "I owe M. Schwartz $10."
Following the recent action of other major producers, the Anaconda Sales Company, a unit of the Anaconda Company, announced yesterday a reduction of 4 cents a pound in its copper prices.

TRENTON, Oct. 18 The State Commission of Investigation said today it was "urgent" to change New Jersey's Medicaid regulations to lower the "grossly excessive" rent payments to some nursinghome owners, many of whom live in New York.

ATLANTA Four and a half years after it went into effect, Jimmy Carter's ambitious reorganization of the government of Georgia is still so controversial that there is hardly anyone in the state government who does not harbor strong feelings about it.
Elliott Maddox, the Yankee outfielder who missed most of this season following Knee surgery, said yesterday he needs another operation on the knee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) President Ford today signed into law a bill providing for mid-decade censuses of the population the first to be in 1985 with subsequent ones to be every 10 years.

Governor Byrne told a Congressional delegation considering the economic problems of the Northeast and Middle West yesterday that reforming the welfare system to provide minimum benefits financed by the Federal Government for recipients countrywide was the first priority facing legislators.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18 Two unreleased tape recordings that have been the focus of considerable interest on the part of defense lawyers for one of the two men accused of having abducted Samuel Bronfman 2d were entered today in the Bronfman kidnapping trial here.

The Band, perhaps North America's most respected rock group, will give a "farewell" concert in San Francisco on Thanksgiving Day, according to spokesmen close to the band and to the many guest artists who are planning to participate.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 18 Prime Minister John Vorster made it clear today that his Government would continue to seclude blacks from participation in the mainstream of South Africa's political life, but he pledged that discriminatory measures that did not serve to limit racial friction would be scrapped.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 18 Six Arab leaders signed a peace plan for Lebanon today calling for a cease-fire this week and creation of a 30,000-man Arab force to supervise the withdrawal of the warring factions.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18 Three more Americans were awarded Nobel Prizes here today Prof. William N. Lipscomb of Harvard University for chemistry and Prof. Burton Richter of Stanford University and Prof. Samuel C.C. Ting of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for physics.

KIBBUTZ AFIKIM, Israel A searing October afternoon in the Jordan Valley. The sun scorches the bald pates of the bleached hills in the distance, siphons precious moisture from the irrigated acres of baking crops and stuns a stroller into near-somnambulism.
PEKING, Oct. 18 A wall poster in Peking has accused Mao Tse-tung's widow, Chiang Ching, of trying to murder her husband.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Supreme Court set the stage today for a major ruling on the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, in a case involving Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic Bronx County chairman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

TOKYO Not expecting any notable achievements, three prominent stock market officials from the United States arrived here a week ago to join some 75 of their counterparts from other countries for the annual meeting ...

With Mayor Beame conceding that "budget cuts have made our sanitationmen somewhat less than omnipresent," a new coalition led by top business executives and the head of the sanitation union yesterday announced a permanent new educational effort "I Love a Clean New York Inc."

HOUSTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) Former Gov. James A. Noe of Louisiana, a Depressionera ally of Huey P. Long and a pioneer in the Louisiana oil industry, died today in a hospital where he had been under treatment for a heart ailment. He was 82 years old and lived in Monroe, La.
Wesley Lunn Wheeler, who designed and built thousand of ships, died last Wednesday in Rye, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

ROME, Oct. 18 Enrico Berlinguer, the Communist Party leader, who is faced with increased dissent among his rank and file, said tonight that the party must help keep the Christian Democrats in power at present to avoid the economic and financial collapse of Italy.
When Marya Mannes dubbed ours the age of wasted miracles, she was referring to television, but the same observation could as easily be applied to frozen foods.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) President Ford today awarded the National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award for distinguished scientific achievement, to 15 scientists, one of them now dead.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuter) Britain is inviting a fourth black nationalist leader, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, to attend the conference on Rhodesia's future that is scheduled to begin in Geneva on Oct. 28, the Foreign Office said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Securities and Exchange Commission intends to make it significantly easier for small companies to raise capital by increasing to perhaps, $2 million the size of securities offerings that can be made with a minimum of red tape and expense, Roderick M. Hills, the agency's chairman, disclosed at a news conference today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 Third-world countries proposed is the Security Council today that an arms embargo be imposed on South Africa to compel it to give up South-West Africa and accede to free elections there under United Nations auspices.

James E. Smith, who resigned in June after a sometimes stormy tour as Comptroller of the Currency, has taken a senior position in the banking industry he formerly regulated. First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, yesterday announced that effective Nov. 1 Mr. Smith, 46 years old, will be joining the bank holding company as executive vice president.

Muhammad Ali won a big decision in a court fight yesterday when a Manhattan jury rejected a boxing referee's $20 million libel suit against the world heavy weight champion.

Muhammad, proposed last week that the group's name be changed to the World. Community of Islam in the West. The change is already in effect, a spokesman said today.

Edward Aguirre, an Arizona-born former teacher of industrial arts, was installed by President Ford yesterday as Commissioner of Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Dr. Aguirre, age 46, has been in San Francisco as H.E.W.'s regional commissioner of education since 1973. He also served four years in Washington and California with the Labor Department's manpower agency.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 18 Gloria Schaffer, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from Connecticut, accused her Republican opponent today of backing out of a series of scheduled debates "now that this campaign has become a horse race."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A major reason that Jimmy Carter holds a lead over President Ford in the race for the Presidency is that he has succeeded in painting a solidly moderate image of himself among the voters.

Thanks to the recent changes in the tax laws, municipal bond funds are coming up like mushrooms after a spring rain. They are a new form of investment, calculated to make it easier for small investors to reach for the tax-exempt features of bonds issued by state and local governments.

HALIFAX, Canada, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Twelve crewmembers were lost and presumed dead and three others were rescued today after they abandoned a shall Dutch freighter sinking in rough seas off Newfoundland, the Canadian Search and Rescue Center said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Air Force's top Middle East intelligence expert today assailed Gen. George S. Brown's comments on Israel's being an American burden as "dangerously irresponsible" and said they were indicative of a growing "tilt against Israel in the Defense Department."
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 19 The National Football League trading deadline passed today and Pat Hughes thinks he got a bad deal.
Gimbel Brothers, one of New York's oldest retailers and the only one with two major Manhattan stores, is striving to end its seven-year earnings drought with a return to profitability next year.

TRENTON, Oct. 19 State Democratic leaders seemed relieved today when Governor Byrne departed at noon for Tokyo, where he will attempt to persuade Japanese car manufacturers to open plants in New Jersey.

Eleanor Clay Ford, the widow of Edsel B. Ford and the mother of Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the board of the Ford Motor Company, died yesterday at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. A resident of Grosse Point Shores, Mich., an affluent. Detroit suburb, she was 80 years old.

It also ended a two-year jinx the Canucks had held over them during which they hadn't won here in six games against Vancouver.

The new Avery Fisher Hall, which has sprung from the skeleton of the old one after some five months of furious reconstruction, officially opened last night with a Pension Fund Concert of the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Pierre Boulez.

LOS ANGELES To get people out of their cars in an effort to cut down on pollution and traffic jams, state officials here recently turned over one lane in each direction of California's busiest freeway to buses and car pools. Reaction among city residents, known for their almost singular devotion to their cars, was fierce and predictable.

Two pilots of note, Gen. James M. Doolittle and Neil A. Armstrong, announced yesterday plans to honor one of the most celebrated aviators with the establishment of the Charles A. Lindbergh Memorial Fund to support the work of young scientists, explorers and conservationists.

Two-way educational broadcasting via communications satellites in space, between widely scattered classrooms on Earth, took a long step forward this week.

The Cincinnati Reds, standing on the threshold of a sweep over the New York Yankees, counted their blessings and saluted their bench last night and decided that neither New York rain nor gloom of night figured to prevent them from completing the job in the 73d World Series.

ARTIST WITH FEELINGS Ben Shahn, the artist, came to the United States from Lithuania in 1906 during the turn-of-the-century waves of migration from Eastern Europe. His paintings, drawings, prints and photographs were always vehicles for the ideas of the social realist. Drawings on Sacco and Vanzetti (two immigrant anarchists executed in 1927 by Massachuetts), for example, displayed the style with which he subsequently became identified.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 20 It has taken Betty Stove four matches over four days to qualify for the $200,000 Colgate Inaugural women's tennis tournament. Why the Dutchwoman had to submit to such indignity baffles her in any of the six languages she speaks.
"New York still is a helluva town," said Osborn Elliott as he was sworn in yesterday as the city's first Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and pledged "a crusade for jobs."

Major chemical companies yesterday reported increases in third-quarter earnings. But the Dow Chemical Company ran against the trend and posted a decline of 22.4 percent in the third quarter.

On Monday The Ladies' Home Journal will be breaking a big new advertising campaign aimed at raising both advertising revenues and circulation. The first ad will also introduce "The Number One Woman," who will be seen throughout the campaign.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct 20 (AP) Henry Niehous, father of a kidnapped Ohio businessman, William F. Niehous, has died of leukemia at the age of 77.

The Bulova Watch Company, one of the country's largest watch makers, is moving its executive headquarters, sales and advertising departments from Rockefeller Center to its Bulova Park facility in Flushing, Queens.

PEKING, Thursday, Oct. 21 (Reuters) The campaign against Mao Tse-tung's widow, Chiang Ching, spilled onto the streets of Peking today with thousands of demonstrators demanding her downfall.

John Stephens Graham, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, died yesterday in George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 71 years old and lived in the capital.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 A group of Jewish dissidents who reported having been beaten by plainclothesmen ended a sit-in at the Supreme Soviet today after being promised a meeting with the Minister of Internal Affairs to discuss emigration policy.

A New Orleans rabbi pondered the bill for college tuition on his desk and said, "My life savings are being tragically depleted and there's no relief in sight. I've had to draw on savings that I thought I'd be able to use for my retirement. I'm feeling pulverized, and each year it gets rougher."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, apparently concerned by mounting criticism that safety questions raised by its technical experts are being stifled by top staff members, has completed a 300-page study of the question.

The American consumer, who went from a mood of pessimism in the last half of 1975 to one of optimism in the first half of this year, now has retreated to a middle position of cautious optimism, Philip Levine, senior vice president and executive research director of Ogihy Mather, told a group of marketing people yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 Thailand's military rulers disclosed today that more than 4,000 people had been arrested since the coup of Oct. 6 on suspicion of being Communist subversives, Nearly two-thirds of them are still in custody, a spokesman for the junta said.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 18 Highfield is to Salisbury as Soweto is to Johannesburg. It is where the men and women that keep Salisbury prosperous and looking sleek have to go to sleep and live the nonworking part of their waking hours. They are not allowed to do so in areas like Salisbury, set apart for Europeans a southern African term for whites.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 The United States military continues to use a former American military base in Thailand as a refueling stop for its reconnaissance planes American officials said today.

The status of Julius Erving appeared to be resolved yesterday. SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 Senator Walter F. Mondale is offering audiences a bland diet of speeches in the closing weeks of the Vice-Presidential campaign. The erotic is tangled in constraint the hand that never gets above Claire's knee, the long night of weighing possibilities at Maude's. The escapes become returns.

Senator James L. Buckley wooed blacks and voters of Chinese, Italian and Polish descent yesterday, appealing to each ethnic group's sense of pride in its heritage and attacking the "big-government programs" supported by his opponent.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 22 Few political issues since Kenya's independence have stirred the popular and academic debate that now surrounds a pending marriage bill, which among other things, would give wives a veto over a husband's polygamous plans, permit wives to share control of family property and send adulterers to jail for six months.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 Let it be everywhere recorded that the time was 8:04 tonight when the Spectrum went dark in anticipation of the dawn of a new era in Philadelphia basketball. The only lights were on the overhead message board, and they spelled: "Is There a Doctor in the House?"

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 195.7 from 197.9 last week. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 200.2 on Oct. 21, 1975.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 21 After two and a half years of sampling with a U-2 plane flying at high altitude, scientists from three American laboratories have found that more than half the larger, naturally occurring dust grains in the stratosphere have come from space.

New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association tentatively accepted a compromise solution yesterday to their long labor dispute, giving the police $1,045 in back pay and what their leaders regard as an improved work schedule.

The New York Stock Exchange reported Wednesday that the short interest in the month ended Oct. 15, 1976, increased by 520,159 to 23,191,653 shares. This was the highest total since July 15, 1976, when the short interest was 24,225,588 shares.

More than 60 of Jacques Barzun's friends and former students from the literary and intellectual world met at a University Club dinner last night for the cultural historian and Columbia University scholar. It includes an unfinished essay that Lionel Trilling, Dr. Barzun's close friend and colleague, was working on at his death last November.

Norman Kramer survives in live television without a hot-comb. BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 22 Mllitary action continued in southern Lebanon today near the Israeli border while the ceasefire that was proclaimed yesterday morning appeared to be effective for the most part in Beirut and the rest of the country.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowiz of New York State said yesterday he was conducting an inquiry into the rights of season ticketholders seeking refunds from the Nets because of the sale of Julius Erving to the Philadelphia 76ers. The Times Mirror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times and three other daily newspapers, announced yesterday that it had offered to buy for $292 million in cash the outstanding stock of Booth Newspapers Inc., publisher of a chain of eight newspapers in Michigan.

A good espionage novel in the Eric Ambler style is TO DIE ELSEWHERE by Theodore Wilden (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $7.95). This is the American debut of a Greek-born writer currently resident in London. The hero is a spy who works for a rather mysterious private intelligence agency. He is a very modern kind of agent, complete with Weltschmerz, cynicism and vast experience.

His campaign is an ego trip.

New York State's Superintendent of Insurance, Thomas A. Harnett, said yesterday that he would require insurance companies to commit themselves to opening their books for new business before he would grant auto-insurance rate increases. In terrain, the Transkei is as fertile and beautiful as any region of Africa.

CAIRO, Oct. 26 As the President of Lebanon, Elias Sarkis, arrived at the Cairo airport for the conference of Arab leaders, the commander of the Egyptian honor guard gave the order to shoulder arms instead of the proper command to come to attention.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 Efforts to unite Rhodesia's faction-ridden black nationalists were under way here today as Ivor Richard of Britain continued his quest for flexibility in the opposed positions of the white and black delegations to the conference on a transition to black rule.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 The policy-making Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party wound up a two-day session today with some personnel changes that left the senior leadership ranks intact.

There are two times in the year when one can scarcely stay indoors. In the spring, when the buds are about to burst, and now, soon after the first hard frost.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP) The British pound slipped to another record low of $1.59 today after steadying briefly as the Government discussed how to recover from yesterday's worst single-day drop in history.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26 (AP) The Mexico Government freed the peso to find its own level in international money markets tonight for the second time in nearly two months, hoping to stem a flight of capital from the country.
The world's biggest team contest begins in the New York area next week. It is the Grand National Teams, which last season attracted an entry of 6,975 teams from all parts of North America.

PARIS, Oct. 26 French schoolchildren work too hard, sleep too little and do not eat enough breakfast. As a result their attention suffers, they do not learn as much as they should and too many of them come down with psychosomatic ailments.

The four-room apartment at 651 West 188th Street, in Washington Heights, was littered with wine bottles and rubbish. Two elderly men lay on the living room floor, dead, it appeared, for more than a week. An elderly woman was semiconscious on the floor of her bedroom. There was no evidence of violence.

PARIS, Oct. 26 The models in their black velvet laced-front bodices and flouncy skirts kicked up their heels, the bride came out doing the can-can, the audience stood up and clapped to keep the rhythm. It was the rousing end to Yves Saint Laurent's astonishing marathon fashion show, which ran more than two hours, spoiled everybody's plans for lunch and included 281 styles, each one of more than passing interest.

WEST POINT, Oct. 26 Capt. Arthur Lincoln, the military lawyer who successfully challenged the United States Military Academy's handling of what became its biggest cheating scandal, is leaving West Point and the Army under pressure.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 Eugene J. McCarthy, an independent candidate for President, was ordered back on the New York State ballot today by the Appellate Division. And, in another decision that also overturned a lower-court ruling, the Appellate Division said that Daniel P. Moynihan, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, was entitled to the Liberal Party line.

CORNUCOPIA Name it china, pottery, jewelry, folk art, patchwork quilts and American, British and European furniture and more and the 33d annual Greenwich village Antiques Show and Sale probably has it, from 35 dealers in six states. The event starts tonight at 7 o'clock with a party benefiting Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (a block south of Sheridan Square); the tab is a tax-deductible $10.

PARIS, Oct. 26 Disquiet is growing on the Continent over Britain's third monetary crisis this year and its implications for world economic and financial stability.

MIAMI BEACH. Oct. 26 (UPI) Candace Mossler Garrison, acquitted in the 1964 death of her millionaire husband in one of the most sensational murder trials of the 1960's, died in her sleep today.
GRIFFIN, Ga., Oct. 26 Charges of political corruption or personal scandal appear to be making little impression on American voters in a number of Congressional races around the country.

That is an area that Israel wants to keep free of Palestinian guerrillas.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 Faced with fiscal and jobs crises that in many respects resemble those of New York City, Mayor Coleman A. Young officially formed today an Economic Growth Council charged to review the city government's operations and tax structure and develop programs to reverse the diminishing jobs trend here, all within the next 12 months.

Cocoa futures, still displaying strength on speculative buying, rose to their previous record high price of $1.28 2/10 yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange and then fell back to close at $1.26 85/100 in terms of the December delivery, up 2 cents a pound from Monday. The record price was first reached last Friday.

Vernon R.Y. Lynn, senior partner in the law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt Mosle, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 35 Sutton Place.

CAIRO, Oct. 26 Arab leaders ended a two-day conference here without final agreement on arrangements for an expanded Arab peacekeeping force for Lebnanon. But their closing statements appeared to imply that Syrian troops already in Lebanon would dominate it.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 26 (AP) Aldo Vera Serafin, a Cuban exile who was once a top police official of the Government of Prime Minister Fidel Castro but later split with him, was shot to death last night as he walked along a street in a San Juan suburb, the police reported today.

TRENTON, Oct. 26 The growing power struggle between New Jersey's 600 school boards and 100,000 teachers and school administrators is expected to intensify during the next two weeks. NORWAY Me., Oct. 26 Dorothy May Travis, founder and first president of the Princeton, N.J., branch of the Colony of the Oranges, died Friday in the Stephens Memorial Hospital here of a gunshot wound inflicted by her husband, Edward P. Travis. She was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) Acting Agriculture Secretary John A. Knebel said today that the Administration was keeping its policy of low interest rates for rural electrification loans to farm cooperatives.

The Federal Communications Commission in a 5-0 vote, with two commissioners absent, yesterday approved the sale of FM radio station WRVR from the Riverside Church to the Sonderling Broadcasting Corporation for $2.3 million.

Gulf and Western Industries Inc., the broadly diversified industrial company, reported yesterday a profit increase of 29.5 percent for the fourth fiscal quarter. It also achieved earnings exceeding $200.2 million on sales of $3 billion for the year ended July 31.

PHOENIX, Oct. 27 (UPI) The Arizona Supreme Court has been asked to intervene in the prosecution of John Harvey Adamson, accused slayer of Don Bolles, an investigative reporter.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) The British price, $1.5720, in late traing today as price of $1.5720 in late trading today as the Labor Government came under increased left-wing pressure to scrap its anti-inflation policies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 President Ford is expected to announce tomorrow a comprehensive United States plan to combat the spread of nuclear weapons. The plan appears to contemplate a multimillion dollar Government program to test the commercial use of plutonium, the raw material of nuclear weapons.
NASHVILLE, Oct. 27 With less than a week left before the election, the close race for the United States Senate in Tennessee has developed into something of a wild-swinging free-for-all.

Buckley yesterday defended his new television commercials disparaging his Democratic rival, Daniel Patrick Moynihan. CAIRO, Oct. 27 The kings, emirs, presidents, foreign ministers and other officials of the 20 Arab nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization who left Cairo today, after the most ambitious and serious attempt of the Arab world.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 28 (Agence France-Presse) Vietnam has warned Thailand to stop what it terms the "persecution" of Vietnamese citizens and has demanded the release of 800 people reportedly interned in concentration camps.

George A. Gottlieb, a real estate man in New York City who in 1943 was president of the Smaller Business Men's Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, died yesterday in the Neurological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center here after a lingering illness. His age was 73.

Maj. Gen. Jack Whitehead Heard, retired, who was commander of the Fifth Armored Division at the outbreak of World War II, a longtime cavalry officer and a self-taught military pilot, died Monday at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio. He was 89 years old.
