NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27 (AP) The captain of a Mississippi River ferry packed with early morning commuters was "almost legally drunk" when his craft crashed with a tanker, killing an estimated 100 people, the New Orleans coroner said today.

The director of New York State's lottery announced yesterday that a new weekly game would begin next month and would operate for five weeks to dispose of the $1.4 million in prize money that the state had been holding from the old weekly Colossus lottery, which was suspended by Governor Carey last year because of mismanagement.

PARIS, Oct. 27 Seven of the men who pulled off "the robbery of the century" last July at Nice are under arrest at Marseilles. They have confessed. And a part of the $8 million haul they made away with after having tunneled their way into a bank has been recovered.

Christianity Today, the Protestant evangelical fortnightly published in Washington, has proposed that Saturday be set aside as a "day of rest" for everybody. Those who choose to join in worship of God on that day could do so, the magazine suggests in its lead editorial for Nov. 5, while those who do not so choose "could spend the time in their own way."

LONDON, Oct 27 A suggestion by Harold Macmillan, a former Conservative Prime Minister, that Britain should have a "government of national unity" to get it out of its economic mess, has been rejected out of hand by both major political parties.
Mildred Morrison Manheimer, a retired high school teacher, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived at 240 Central Park South.

Lloyd McBride, a candidate to succeed I.W. Abel as president of the United Steelworkers of America, announced yesterday that Joseph Odorcich of McKeesport, Pa., was joining his ticket as candidate for vice president for administration.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 The Soviet leadership, buoyed by a bumper grain harvest, today announced production goals for 1977, that it hoped would help significantly narrow the Soviet Union's economic gap with the United States by the end of the current decade.

McCarthy of Minnesota as an independent Presidential candidate in the state election.

Less than a decade ago, a candy-loving child on a tight allowance could budget a nickel for a daily chocolate bar. But those days have gone as the price of chocolate has steadily risen. Yesterday, the Hershey Foods Corporation and M M/Mars announced new prices that raise the cost of chocolate bars by 5 cents.

If two such well-advised people as Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter can't agree on the status of the American economy, where are we to turn for enlightenment? I turned to Leonard Silk's "The Economists" profiles of five leading economists, three of them Nobel laureates, by a member of the editorial board of The New York Times my theory being that I'd understand the economy better if I understood what the experts think.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 This week, Eugene J. McCarthy has been in Ohio, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania and by week's end will have carried his message to Arizona and California.
Dr. Joseph H.N. Jones, a retired general practitioner, died Monday at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Cendre, L.I. He was 87 years old and lived in Freeport, L.I.

Retired hotel employees held a rally at their union's headquarters on West 44th Street yesterday and then some of the elderly group marched to the offices of the Hotel Association of New York City to protest what they called the failure of the hotels to increase their pensions to $80 a month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The Government spent $7.6 billion less in the JulySeptember quarter than it expected to as recently as July, and for the first nine months of the year spent $11.4 billion less than it estimated in January, according to official figures released today.

Gloria Schaffer, Connecticut's Secretary of the State and Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, said today that she would complain to the Federal Elections Commission that the Mobil Oil Corporation, through a newspaper advertisment, had illegally supported her opponent.
ORLANDO Fla., Oct. 27 (AP) A Federal jury today found former Senator Edward J. Gurney not guilty of a charge of lying to a 1974 grand jury about a massive political shakedown scheme.
Russell A. Bufalino, the reputed Mafia chief of northeastern Pennsylvania, was arrested yesterday in an alleged extortion scheme to use "physical violence and threats" to collect a $25,000 debt.

In an age of superheated viruosos, the American pianist Grant Johannesen goes his quiet way, specializing in the French literature for the piano, playing this music calmly, elegantly, and with extraordinary finish of style. In common with earlier composer-lyricist series at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., the shows are entertaining for the audience and challenging for the sometimes stagestruck writers. One sure result is that they will have greater sympathy for their professional interpreters.

Gustave L. Levy, senior partner of Goldman, Sachs Company, on Tuesday suffered what a spokesman for the investment firm described yesterday as "a mild stroke." Mr, Levy was admitted to Mount Sinai Hospital, where he remained last night.

In trading marked by wide price swings and heavy volume, soybeans yesterday gained 220 cents a bushel, the November contract ending at $6.73.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) The nation's trade balance slipped deeper into the red in September as imports exceeded exports by $778.9 million, the Commerce Department reported today. The figure, wider than August's deficit of $757.7 million, brought to $3.4 billion the total trade deficit for 1976.
The Abercrombie Fitch Company, which filed for voluntary bankruptcy status Aug. 9, is offering charge and other customers a one-time, 10 percent price reduction through the Christmas season.

BETWEEN an artist's myth and the reality of his life and work there are inevitably certain discrepancies. The myth seizes on extremes of feeling, whereas the reality more often than not is a subtler mixture of more variegated emotions and perceptions. And while such myths always have an obvious appeal, they are never sufficient for a complete understanding of either the artist or his work.

Chamaedorea elegans (parlor palm). The dark green feathery leaves of this dwarf palm, which rarely exceeds two feet in height, are a decorator's standard. It is one of the few palms that flower regularly indoors but the whole inflorescence looks like little more than a bunch of diminutive green lentils. Parlor palms are usually grown several to a pot for lushness. They like a warm climate (average 75 degrees) and low light.

CAIRO, Oct. 28 A cautious and tentative liberalization of Egyptian political life began formally today as millions of voters elected a parliament in the first relatively free voting in Egygt since the early 1950's during the rule of King Farouk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 President Ford today formally announced a broad new Government program to prevent nuclear materials intended for peaceful purposes from being used for atomic weapons, and Jimmy Carter, the Democratic nominee for President, charged it was "too little and too late."

CLARK, Oct. 28 Representatives of the business community today told 100 high school seniors attending a symposium at the Ramada Inn that government regulations had grown to "monstrous proportions" and were adding millions of dollars to costs that had to be passed on to the consumers.
ONTPELIER, Vt. As the first shows dust the Green Mountains, Vermont is seeing hard-fought political campaigns that are sorely testing its growing, but now divided, Democratic Party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The responses of President Ford and Jimmy Carter to a questionnaire on proposed Government reform were released today.
ATLANTA, Oct. 28 Contrary to early assumptions, Jimmy Carter could lose some Southern states in next Tuesday's election, according to political specialists in the region.

ONE of the big books of St. Martin's Press for the fall is "A Vision Shared," a compilation of photographs from the work of eleven photographers of the Farm Security Administration. The book covers the period 1935-1943 and reflects the Diaghilev-like guidance of Roy Stryker, not a photographer himself, but the motivating force behind the men and women who produced an unparalleled record of our country during those years.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 The domestic auto industry is targeting production of about 803,000 cars next month on its way to a fourth-quarter schedule of 2,195,000 units. The fourth-quarter total would be up 13.6 percent from last year's 1,932,000. But it would still be 16 percent below the fourth-quarter output record of 2,624,000 set in 1965.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 28 Two special prosecutors have been appointed by Venezuela's Attorney General to prepare charges against six persons arrested here as suspects in the crash of a Cuban airliner off Barbados.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the State Court of Appeals today delayed an order that had removed Eugene J. McCarthy from the state ballot as an independent candidate for the Presidency.

Warren Bower, professor emeritus of English and a former assistant dean of New York University's School of Continuing Education, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at the Salmagundi Club, at 45 Fifth Avenue.
James C. Maloney, a veteran blimp pilot, died yesterday at his home in Akron, Ohio, after a long illness. He was 58 years old.
The Cincinnati Reds began to collect the spoils of their latest victory yesterday when Johnny Bench was honored as the hero of their World Series sweep of the New York Yankees.

John H. Lichtblau, executive director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said yesterday that the oil exporting nations could only justify a price increase of somewhere between 2.7 and 7.8 percent if they based it on "how much prices of things they must import have risen."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct.29 Lebanon's ' cease-fire held up today despite overnight clashes between right-wing Christian forces and leftist Moslems in the eastern suburbs of the capital.

Jackson of Washington captured 10 out of 11 Democratic Presidential delegates within the Town of Hempstead, and 17 of 22 delegates in Nassau County. San Juanico is a bridge in the Philippines that connects the islands of Leyte and Samar. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 When diplomats sit around these days discussing the American election, it is the apparent apathy of the public more than the policies of the candidates that stirs their interest.

The Presidency of Ireland is principally a ceremonial post; its occupant has no more political power than Britain's Queen. But one of his functions could be a vital safeguard in a democratic system: before signing into law a bill passed by Parliament, he can ask the Supreme Court to rule on its constitutionality.

MUNICH, West Germany Georg Hagn-Sternecker, a 72-year-old Bavarian farmer, does not feel out of place wearing a pair of embroidered Lederhosen and a green Alpine hat in the elegant streets of Munich. "Why not?" he says. "Munich is Bavaria too, isn't it?"

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 31 Just when it seemed Keystone Ore was going to become the first horse since 1970 to win all three legs of pacing's triple crown, clinch 3-year-old honors and take a giant step toward gaining the horse-of-the-year award, along came Windshield Wiper with a late rush last night to thwart one goal and check the impetus toward the other two.

ATLANTA, Oct. 31 The Plains Baptist Church, where Jimmy Carter is a deacon, locked its doors and refused to hold services today rather than admit four blacks in violation of a resolution passed in 1965 barring Negroes and "civil rights agitators."

PARIS, Oct. 31 In the business and financial centers of Europe an air of gloom is spreading over prospects for the world economy and its capacity to tackle the mounting problems of debt management, sluggish growth and rising unemployment.

ABC-TV announced yesterday that it was no longer planning to expand the "Evening News with Harry Reasoner and Barbara Walters" from half an hour to 45 minutes or an hour. The announcement came within days of a similar statement by NBC.

On the eve of the election in New Jersey, leaders of both parties believe that President Ford is the more popular candidate and that if Jimmy Carter is to win it will depend on how well the urban Democratic organizations do their jobs.

Rosa Belfiore has a voice as pretty as her name, and she displayed it to generally good purpose in her Alice Tully Hall debut recital on Tuesday night. The New York soprano has to her credit appearances in Italian opera houses, and she has studied in Italy as well as in this city.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 Citizens of this city have recently started a concerted campaign to break the commercial sex industry here and chase it out of town.
MIAMI, Oct. 31 Two women vying for a seat on the State Public Commission have enlivened somewhat the otherwise listless political campaign in Florida.

OLD FRIENDS... Three seasoned pros, Myron Cohen, Geraldine Fitzgerald and Allan Jones, are still doing what comes naturally and, judging from their reviews, are teaching today's youngsters in show business more than a thing or two.

About 250 mourners gathered in front of the charred remains of the Club Puerto Rico in the Morrisania section of the Bronx yesterday to recite the rosary for the 25 men and women who perished in a fire-believed set by an arsonistthat swept through the club a week earlier.

BEDFORD, N.Y, Oct. 31 At first it seemed as though this year's Sport Swap might turn out to be a bit less tony than last year's, which featured a child's white-water kayak, but then a Gordon setter walked in, one of four pedigreed hunting dogs for sale, and everybody smiled.

HARTFORD, Oct. 31 Even behind the brave campaign rhetoric, the Republicans expect to do well in the elections in Connecticut on Tuesday, almost certainly winning another term in the United States Senate for Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and hanging on to the two of the six Connecticut seats in the United States House of Representatives that the Republicans now hold.
His new job is bringing Aaron wildavsky back home to New York City again. "I've lived away for almost 20 years, and that's been too long," he said yesterday. "It's time for me to come home."

A missing 23-year-old Hillsdale, N.J., sailor who set out a month ago to circumnavigate the world alone in a 31-foot sloop was sighted by a Coast Guard search plane 500 miles east of Puerto Rico yesterday, adrift but apparently unhurt.

The Council on Wage and Price Stability has served notice on United States automobile manufacturers that it sees no basis for any further increase in prices on 1977 cars. An announcement by the American Motors Corporation last week indicating that it lost money heavily in the 1976 fiscal year has aroused fresh concern in Wall Street that the No. 4 auto maker may not survive.

Robert Joffrey has never hesitated to ask choreographers of genius to provide his company with special ballets. Why ask anyone less? Denise Jackson was partnered sensitively by Kevin McKenzie in George Balanchine's luscious showpiece.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 In a Presidential election year, gubernatorial contests rarely attract much national attention. This year there are only 14 such contests, and, with one exception, they involve middle-sized or small states of modest political impact.

GREENVALE, L.I., Oct. 31 A "Ragtime Spectacular" bringing together what Dave Jasen, a ragtime specialist who teaches at the C.W. Senator Walter F. Mondale swept into New York City last night, continuing his down-to-the-wire effort to shore up narrow Democratic margins in some key states and possibly tip the balance in others by enhancing the crucial turnout of his party's voters east of the Mississippi tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 31 Scores of Christian Arab citizens of Israel have recently volunteered to serve in the Israeli defense forces, apparently in appreciation of Israel's military assistance to the Lebanese Christians in their civil war.

On her first day as a broker on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange last Thursday thereby becoming the first woman member in the history of the Big Board to spend all of her working time there Alice Jarcho took a hard fall.

HAVANA, Oct. 31 Flying to Havana aboard a Cuban airliner can be a strain. There are three security checks of passengers and their luggage before they board weekly Flight 455 at Kingston, Jamaica. A fourth check is performed by the crew of the Ilyushin-18 at the door of the four-engine plane, where even tiny transparent plastic bottles containing vitamins or aspirin are removed from handbags and emptied for inspection.
The Treasury is selling $6 billion of new notes and bonds later this week, but the Government securities that once attracted individual investors have lost much of their lure.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 31 A few years ago when the world was a little younger and a great deal more innocent, the very idea of the Royal Danish Ballet doing anything that might conceivably have been thought of as modern would have been literally inconceivable. The Royal Danes were all light, grace and Bournonville, their famous 19th-century choreographer who has forever left his imprint on their repertory.

President Ford and Jimmy Carter will make their final appeals to the national electorate tonight in half-hour paid political broadcasts to be seen in "prime time" on each of the three television networks.

Kristen Matina Kenny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Kenny of North Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Avery Heisler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Heisler of New York. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Royden C. Richardson of Centerville, Mass., at his home.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 31 (AP) Jack Nicklaus, blazing away from the field with a four-under-par 32 on the front nine today, scored a four-stroke victory in the $160,000 Australian open golf tournament.

Senator James L. Buckley and his Democratic-Liberal opponent, Daniel P. Moynihan, made their final joint appearance of the campaign yesterday in what turned out to be a debate on issues and an exchange of pleasantries with barbs.

OCOEE, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) The City Council of this Central Florida town, which stopped taxing its elderly citizens last year, has taken another innovative action this one designed to get out the vote Tuesday.

Dr. Douglas Danford Bond, a wellknown psychiatrist and former dean of Case Western Reserve School of Medicine in Cleveland, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Cleveland. He was 65 years old.

CBS has decided not to pick up its option on the remainder of a threeyear contract with the North American Soccer League. Codd declared yesterday that the demand by the police union for amnesty to officers accused of disorderly behavior in the demonstrations earlier this fall was "totally unrealistic." The Boise Cascade Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase price, an average of 4 percent on its uncoated free sheet and groundwood printing and publishing papers, effective Jan, 1. The increases range from $20 to $35 a ton. The products account for about 900,000 tons of the company's annual total output of 2.5 million tons. Uncoated white papers are used for business stationery. Groundwood papers are utilized in paperback books and some magazines.

The very names of Virginia taverns seem to conjure up visions of rabblerousing Colonists exchanging the latest news over tankards of ale and bites of marrow pudding. Taverns served as meeting places, militia headquarters and sites of slave auctions. They bustled with conversation, cockfights and billiard games while merchants hawked their wares. Historical greats--Washington, Jefferson, Henry, Monroe, George Mason--danced, drank, dined and politicked around tavern tables, setting the mood for revolution.

THE Island's location between the ocean and the Sound provides us with a favored winter climate for plants. Then a jazzier band tried to succeed on its own while Mr. Clayton-Thomas began a solo career.
The United Federation of Teachers has sued in Federal Court in Manhattan for an injunction to forestall the union's loss of the dues checkoff as a penalty for an illegal five-day strike last fall.

The charges of discrimination leveled against the city's public school system by the Federal Government contain an odd mixture of legitimate and illogical criticism. The report by the Civil Rights Office of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare exposes practices which work to the detriment of racial minorities and of women in the competition for teaching and supervisory jobs. Regrettably, the investigators have confused what is theoretically desirable with what is practically attainable.

It not only offers a generally good repertory, but it also has an unusuaity high level of production values.

He was 85 years old:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Catholic bishops of the United States approved today by a vote of 172 to 25 a pastoral letter on morality that strongly reaffirms the Roman Catholic Church's traditional teachings on sexual ethics in the face of rising discontent within the church. The letter repeats the moral stands in the Vatican's "Declaration on Sexual Ethics" issued earlier this year.

PATERSON, Nov. 11 The half-century-old Fabian Theater, once a major motion-picture hall in the metropolitan area, will present Saturday night a world premiere benefit performance of "Communion," a murder mystery filmed largely in this city.

Walter Piston, a distinguished American composer and teacher of music who won the Pulitzer Prize for Music in 1948 and 1961, died yesterday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 82 years old.

The father of modern hairdressing flew in from California this week to keep an eye on the launching, at Bloomingdale's, of his first retail hair products.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12--Lawyers for Patricia Hearst asked Judge William H. Orrick Jr. in Federal District Court today to release her on bail pending appeal of her conviction for bank robbery. Judge Orrick said he would study the motion. He is expected to rule in several days.

Dr. Glenn Olds, the educator who was called in to restore tranquillity at Kent State University after the shootings in 1970 in which National Guardsmen killed four students, resigned Thursday night, but the university trustees rejected his resignation. Dr. Olds, who took over as president in 1971, told the trustees in a long letter that the "tasks of healing and restoration" had been completed.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 12--A key witness who testified for the prosecution 10 years ago at the first murder trial of Robin (Hurricane) Carter gave new and potentially more-damaging testmony today in the second day of the second trial of Mr. Carter and John Artis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)--The Justice Department is looking into the possibility of bid rigging in the sale of timber in national forests in California, a spokesman said today.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 11--A Federal court ruling ordering Mobile to scrap its city government and replace it with a new one more favorable to blacks has generated a storm of protest in this city, including a petition drive to impeach the judge.

ATLANTA, Nov. 12 (AP)--Rick Hampton, a defenseman, scored a thirdperiod goal on a power play and gained the Cleveland Barons a 3-3 tie with the Atlanta Flames tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Business loans at large commercial banks across the nation rose $847 million in the week ended Nov. 3 to a total outstanding of $114.5 billion, data re-- leased yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.

In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee this week, Chairman Arthur Burns of the Federal Reserve Board said he wanted to "cooperate" with the Carter Administration, but apparently only on his own terms. Indeed, his statement was interpreted as a warning to Mr. Carter that the Fed is prepared for a confrontation, if the new Administration seeks to promote a faster recovery by applying greater fiscal stimulus.

A jury convicted 17 defendants and acquitted four others of conspiracy charges yesterday at the end of a three-month trial involving a major ring accused of importing and selling hundreds of millions of dollars worth of narcotics.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12--The General Assembly approved a Cyprus resolution today again demanding the withdrawal of Turkish troops that have occupied part of the island for two years.

Alice Lawrence Behn of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Prof. Harry Behn, was married yesterday to Dr. Walter F. Goebel, also of Greenwich. The ceremony was performed at Dr. Goebel's home by the Rev. Samuel Walker of Christ Episcopal Church.

TOKYO, Nov. 12--The Japanese Government adopted a program today to accelerate the current slowed pace of Japan's economic recovery.

Akin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Raymond C. Akin of Frewsburg. N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gary Hall, the associate pastor.

PLAINS, Ga., Nov.14--With three Ku Klux Klansmen parading outside and the Rev. Clennon King, a black minister, huddled in a stairwell of an outside entrance, the congregation of Jimmy Carter's church voted today to drop its 11-yearold ban on attendance by blacks. It decided to set up a committee to screen all applications for membership, black or white, without regard to race, and to retain its minister, who had opposed its ban on blacks.

On March 24, 1945, Roscoe C. Brown Jr. maneuvered his P-51 Mustang fight er plane into position behind a German Messerschmitt-262 high above Berlin and became one of the first pilots to shoot down a jet aircraft.

TUNIS, Nov. 14 (AP)--Moufida Bourguiba, divorced wife of President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia, has died at her home at the age of 86, the ruling Destourian Socialist party announced today. The cause of death was not disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--A Justice Department spokesman has said that Dr. Orlando Bosch is still wanted by the United States Parole Commission for violation of parole two years ago.

HONG KONG, Nov. 14 (UPI)--Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania put on one of his worst court performances today and virtually threw away his match against Ken Rosewall of Australia in the $75,000 Hong Kong international tournament. Rosewall, playing one of the best games of his career, won 1-6, 6-4, 7-6, 6-0, and walked away with the $10,500 winner's check.

Antonio Zapeda, who presented a solo concert at the Kitchen on Saturday, is a performer in danger of being upstaged by his instruments. He plays preColumbian drums, rattles, whistles and flutes, some of them original, others made by Mexican Indian craftsmen according to models unearthed from archeological digs. Each instrument has a bewitching and, to these ears at least, a novel sound.

St. Francis Prep did just what it had to yesterday and as a result the Terriers are champions of the Catholic Schools Football League City Division. The Terriers defeated Holy Cross, 7-0. at St. John's University in Queens and retained their city title.
A week-long recruitment drive for Boy Scouts in New York City will start today, sponsored by the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America.

The Baltimore Colts went into yesterday's National Football League game against the New England Patriots at Baltimore with some impressive credentials. They were the league's top offensive team with 278 points and had won 17 of their last 18 regular-season games, eight of nine this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--A public interest law group charged today that there had been a "startling plunge" in the number of audits of large corporations done by the Internal Revenue Service and that the decline in these audits had cost the Government at least $1.5 billion in uncollected taxes in 1975.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 14 (UPI)--Mayor Beame quipped about New York's shaky budget today when a delegation of American mayors arrived for a 10-day visit in Israel.

"My Fair Lady," the popular revival of the Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical adapted from Shaw's "Pygmalion," will move from the St. James Theater after the matinee of Dec. 5 to take up residence at the LuntFontanne Theater on Dec. 8. Jan Richardson, Christine Andreas, George Rose snd Robert Coote will continue as the show's stars.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 15 The Suffolk County Legislature, adding $1.7 million to the budget of the County Executive, John V.N. Klein, adopted today a $578 million budget for 1977.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Supreme Court ruled 7-2 today that a convict who is paroled before serving his full sentence and who is then convicted and imprisoned for a second crime, committed while on parole, has no constitutional right to an immediate parole revocation hearing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Securities and Exchange Commission outlined today a proposal under which disputes between investors and their brokers involving up to $5,000 could be resolved without resort to expensive and time-consuming litigation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 Brazilians voted today in municipal elections that are widely viewed here as another step in the slow process of political liberalization promised by the right-wing military dictatorship.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 15 (UPI) Dr. Charles E. Friedgood, on trial for the murder of his wife, reddened in anger today during testimony by a former detective who helped intercept the physician and take him from a plane at Kennedy International Airport.

HACKENSACK, Nov. 15 (UPI) Eight persons were arrested today in Bergen, Hudson and Passaic Counties on charges of operating an illegal lottery, allegedly backed by organized crime.

A nationwide air-traffic slowdown was averted yesterday when the Civil Service Commission supplied the flight controllers' union with acceptable assurances on the effect of a new pay-scale decision.
Jean Gabin, the craggy and sardonic hero-victim of a hundred French films, died yesterday of a heart attack at the American Hospital in Neuilly, on the edge of Paris. He was 72 years old.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Everyone said the "Treasures of Tutankhamen" show would be magnificent, and everyone was right.

A growing body of evidence suggests that the system used to determine automobile insurance rates is based, in part, on faulty statistics and unfairly burdens groups of drivers who can least afford to pay the highest premiums.
Edwin J. Barry a limited partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Phelen, Silver, Vesce, Barry Co., died Sunday in his home at 240 Long Hill Drive in Short Hills, N.J. He was 86 years old.
The closeness of the vote in the Presidential election has once again revived interest in reform or abolition of the Electoral College.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The Navy is seeking to revive its Condor missile program that was canceled earlier this year by Congress after the weapon became entangled in technical difficulties and suggestions of conflict of interest on the part of Pentagon officials.
The Community Service Society accused the Beame administration yesterday of "dragging its feet" on Charter revision, especially in regard to the decentralization of city government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Everyone said the "Treasures of Tutankhamen" show would be magnificent, and everyone was right.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 15 Carmen Cozza, the most successful football coach in Yale University history, announced tonight that he was stepping down to devote full time to his duties as athletic director. He made the announcement at the team banquet.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive, requested today a 1977 Westchester budget that included a relatively small increase over the current year, a slight decrease in the county's average property tax and a pledge not to increase welfare spending next year "by a single cent" over this year's figure.

It took more time to decide the team champion at the IC4A cross-country meet yesterday than it did for Curt Alitz of Army to win the individual title. The 21-year-old Cadet, the runnerup last year, covered the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in 23 minutes 58.1 seconds and finished 25 yards ahead of John Flora of Northeastern in the University Division.
MOSCOW, Nov. 15 The Soviet authorities today released two Jewish dissidents who had faced the possibility of up to five years in prison for protests in downtown Moscow last month.
PARIS, Nov. 15 (UPI) The new beaujolais wine went on sale today with both higher alcoholic content and higher prices.

The Municipal Labor Committee, made up of unions representing more than 200,000 New York City workers, voted unanimously yesterday against a suggestion by Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, that collective bargaining be suspended for the duration of the city's fiscal crisis.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 Israeli Government officials are reluctantly conceding the effectiveness of a recent series of Arab diplomatic and political moves in the complex search for peace in the Middle East.

An East Side landlord did not want the "Hidden Desire" massage parlor as a tenant, and so, upon the advice of a city official, he hired three detectives from the Always Zon Guard agency, who visited the massage parlor and paid three women to perform sex acts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 The United States Public Health service announced today that there would be no large-scale, swine flu immunization effort for Americans in the 3-through-17-year-old age group because only limited supplies of vaccine suitable for children would be available this year.

The state's special nursing-home prosecutor said yesterday that he had found a widespread pattern of kickbacks in the health-care industry in New York State, with suppliers paying up to one-third the value of the contract being paid by the suppliers to set the business.

The relatively low turnout in the Presidential election appears to reflect demographic factors, as well as a sense of powerlessness among the less privileged and the young, rather than active disillusionment with the American system or institutions of government, according to a survey conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.
PEKING, Nov. 15 (Reuters) China tonight flatly rejected any return to friendly relations with the Soviet Union following the death of Mao Tse-tung.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 15 (Reuters At least nine black Africans were killed and 55 injured last night in fighting at the Impala platinum mine at Wildebeestfontein, 60 miles northwest of Johannesburg, a police spokesman said today.

Barney H. Rubine, who in 1915 founded the Hudson Iron and Meta1 Company in Bayonne, N.J., died Sunday at the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Jersey City. He was 87 years old and was a lifelong resident of Bayonne, having been brought there as an infant from Russia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) The House Committee on Assassinations, meeting formally for the first time, announced today that a study group of 170 persons would conduct what it hoped will be the definitive investigations of the murders of President Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

John P. Stevens Jr., who retired in 1965 as chairman of J.P. Stevens Company, the textile concern that was founded by his father and that grew into one of the giants of the industry, died Sunday at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 79 years old.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 15 The jury in the second murder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis was told today that one of the victims of the 1966 Lafayette Grill shootings who was shot in the head but survived failed to identify the who defendants when they were brought by the police to his hospital room here.

Berta N. Briggs, painter and writer, who had been active in New York City's cultural activities for many years, died Friday at the De Witt Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 92 years old and lived at 40 East 96th Street.

Justice William C. Hecht Jr., a retired justice of the State Supreme Court and a special referee for that court, died Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 430 East 86th Street.

Now here's a hot item: Helitzer Advertising, specialists in advertising to the young, has become the agency for Hot Items Inc., a toy company with headquarters in Newark. Helitzer said its new client would be spending a record $1 million in TV this spring. The previous agency was Robert S. Block in Milwaukee.

Governor Carey's dream of forging a strong regional alliance to press for more Federal aid for the depressed Northeast moved a big step forward last weekend at a conference in Saratoga Springs sponsored by the infant Coalition of Northeastern Governors.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 Chiding those who would compare SovietYugoslav relations with those of "the Wolf and Little Red Ridinghood," Leonid I. Brezhnev arrived here today for three days of talks with President Tito.

Three elderly men accused of killing civilians in Nazi-occupied Europe more than 30 years ago appeared in Federal courtrooms yesterday to face rare deportation proceedings for allegedly lying about their past so they could immigrate here after World War II.
Five 2-year-old colts with one major goal provided the theme of yesterday's $36,675 Nashua Stakes at Aqueduct. The big incentive? To register a first stakes victory.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the details of its expected staff reorganization, involving the dismissal of about 125 employees, including nine officers.

The relatively low turnout in the Presidential election appears to reflect demographic factors, as well as a sense of powerlessness among the less privileged and the young, rather than active disillusionment with the American system or institutions of government, according to a survey conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.
The stock market, reacting favorably yesterday to comments made by President-elect Jimmy Carter, posted a moderate gain in continued slow trading.

Medicaid reimbursement fees for the most frequently ordered laboratory tests will be reduced by up to one-half, thereby saving the program an estimated total of $3 million a year, New York City's Medicaid Administration announced yesterday.
VIENNA, Nov. 15 Economic experts of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met here today for secret discussions on proposals to put up the price of crude oil by 10 to 25 percent.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) The price of gold went up sharply in the major bullion markets today, hitting its highest point in London since the beginning of the year to close at $139.50 an ounce. Dealers said investors in the United States and the Far East were buying gold.

Another problem we have in New York is children beating up grandmothers. Sometimes they kill them, although the usual thing is just robbery. Sometimes the children are quite young. Ten, twelve, thirteen years old. Sometimes the grandmothers are old enough to be great-grandmothers. The other day two pubescent boys did a street-mugging job on a woman who later told policemen she was 103.
TRENTON, Nov. 15 The State Department of Health is preparing a regulation that would close or consolidate on a regional basis hospital maternity wards that deliver fewer than l,000 babies a year.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 American new-car sales for the Nov. 1-10 period declined 1.5 percent from last year because of what analysis said was the lingering impact of the Ford Motor Company strike and uncertainty about the overall economy.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 15 A Nassau County police officer was shot and killed last night when another policeman's service revolver discharged accidentally in a struggle with an 18-year-old suspect seized after a chase in a stolen car, the Nassau County police said today.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15 (AP) Mario Tremblay, Yvan Cournoyer and Doug Risebrough all scored in the second period, leading the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 15 The defense rested today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 If the Korean businessman Tongsun Park does not return to the United States, that will further complicate an investigation already burdened by questions of diplomatic immunity, access to offshore bank accounts and the legal value of foreign intelligence data, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Tuesday, Nov. 16 A deadline ran out at midnight on attempts by the Malaysian Government to reach production sharing agreements with Shell and Exxon oil companies and, despite last-minute talks, the two sides failed to announce a compromise.
LISBON, Nov. 15 (UPI) An explosion today outside the home of former Agriculture Minister Antonio Lopes Cardoso caused extensive damage but no injuries, a police spokesman said.

The American Distilling Company announced yesterday that it had been holding exploratory discussions with the Rapid-American Corporation to acquire Rapid's Schenley Industries subsidiary for a $355 million package of cash and notes.
TRENTON, Nov. 15 (AP) A special study shows that nearly one-fourth of all students who enter high schools in New Jersey never graduate.

The prosecutor in a Federal heroinsmuggling trial reported yesterday that the wife of the Government's chief witness had "apparently been kidnapped" in an attempt to prevent the witness from testifying.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 16 Samuel Bronfman 2d, making his first appearance at the trial of his two alleged kidnappers, testified today that his life had repeatedly been threatened by the armed and masked man who allegedly seized him in August of 1975 at the garage of his mother's estate in Purchase.

New York City's Department of Mental Health and its consultants "heartily recommend" that the Brewster Hotel be used as a social-rehabilitation center for the mentally disabled, West Side residents were told at a public hearing last night.

THE Miss World beauty contest in London is faced with a depleting list of candidates. Miss India, 18-year-old Naina Balsa ver, yesterday became the fourth contestant to walk out of the competition. Miss Balsaver withdrew at the request of her government in protest over South Africa's apartheid policies. South Africa is sending two candidates one black and one white. Contestants from Mauritius, Swaziland and Liberia already have quit the contest in protest.
Consumer spending will strengthen "in the period immediately ahead," A. Dean Swift, president of Sears Roebuck Company, predicted yesterday.

TORONTO, NOV. 16 In the aftershock, of the separatist election in Quebec, Robert Stewart stood at the long bar in the Sheraton Centre Hotel, where lunctime patrons from Toronto's financial and governmental district gazed solemnly out a huge plate-glass window, peering across City Hall Plaza to where the redand-white maple leaf flag of Canada flapped in the breeze.

Jon Matlack, the left-hander who reached a personal six-year high with 17 victories this year, has signed a three-year contract with the New York Mets for an estimated $100,000 a year, the club announced yesterday.
Oil will remain "very reasonably priced" even after the coming meeting to consider a price increase, the Saudi Arabian ambassador to the United States said yesterday in New York.

Representatives of insurance broker associations warned yesterday that large numbers of motorists would start driving without insurance if the state approved proposed increases in automobile assigned risk rates. In some cases the rates would more than double.

For the last several years, a mysterious Korean "businessman" known as Tongsun Park has been exceptionally active in Washington political and social circles. He was the chief organizer of a luxurious private club in Georgetown where, according to one informed estimate, about 300 members of Congress were entertained at parties at one time or another. But entertainment was only the beginning of Mr. Park's activities.

Lieut, Frederick P. Borman, a 1974 West Point graduate and a son of a former astronaut, Col. Frank Borman, was cleared by the Army yesterday of an allegation that he had taken a $1,200 bribe. The charges alleged that he received the money to fix a case involving two cadets who had been accused of cheating at the United States Military Academy.

The Rev. Dr. Cyril Charles Richardson, internationally known church historian and Washburn professor emeritus of church history at Union Theological Seminary in New York, died yesterday morning in his home after a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street in Manhattan.
State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday that the Beame administration had failed to implement half of the revisions in the City Charter that were supposed to be in place by next Jan. 1.
SUDDENLY, prime-time television is a feast, its usually sparse bill of fare lush with more enticements than a glut tonous viewer could possibly consume.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 The Ford Administration has quietly approved an emergency loan of $300 million to Portugal and has decided to seek Congressional approval to join in a long-term $1.5 billion consortium to help the newly formed Government of Mario Soares stay in power.
CHICAGO, Nov.16 (AP) Soybean futures pushed 23 cents a bushel higher on the Chicago Board of Trade today, erasing a similar decline of the previous session.
Eleanor Brown Dowling, a former magazine editor, died Monday at the Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L.I.
Robert M. Burns, a retired chemical engineer, died Sunday at his Concord, Mass., home. He was 86 years old.

PARIS, Nov. 16 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is consid ering postponing a crucial price meeting next month from which increases have been predicted that could aim a new blow at the world economy.

The current wave of takeovers the strongest since the nineteen-sixties may reflect fears by conglomerates and other acquisitive companies that new antitrust law will hamper acquisitions, both friendly and unfriendly, in the future.

PEKING, Nov. 16 (Reuters) China's northern earthquake zone was recovering today from a severe jolt that rocked major cities almost 400 miles apart.
New Yorkers lining up to make the first payments on Christmas Clubs that will not ripen until next fall have an important new advantage working for them.

So widespread has wine drinking become today that a dinner table lacking something deep red, rosy pink or pale white on it looks almost inhospitable, as if some understood pleasure was about to be withheld.
In a move that could have long-range impact on the ways by which companies raise capital, the Exxon Corporation went directly to the public yesterday to borrow money.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 16 (UPI) Pledges and money reported by United Way campaigns in the United States and Canada are 8.8 percent higher than those reported at this time last year, the United Way of America headquarters said today.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board has let it be known that he does not necessarily oppose a tax cut and would even be willing to support one to improve the economy's performance and reduce unemployment provided that it was the kind of tax cut that Dr. Burns thought would do the job.

Rutgers, which finally achieved ranking among the nation's top 20 college football teams, will meet once-beaten Colgate Thanksgiving night in Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. For four generations, members of the prominent Uihlein family headed the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company and worked to established their product as "the Beer that Made Milwaukee Famous." WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (Reuters) A Federal judge ruled today that the Justice Department's 1974 antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company may proceed, despite the company's contention that the department was invading the jurisdiction of the Federal Communications Commission.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) Amoco cut gasoline prices by 1 cent a gallon in all of its marketing regions around the nation today, a company spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 In a rare intervention in a still undecided tender offer, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Royal Industries had issued incomplete and inaccurate statements in connection with a hotly contested takeover bid against it by Monogram Industries.

TRENTON, Nov. 16 Opening with a re-enactment by 500 uniformed troops of General Washington's Delaware River crossing on Christmas Eve 1776, New Jersey will celebrate "10 crucial days" of the nation's revolutionary birth with a lavish cultural and historical festival beginning Dec. 25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Four years ago, Dr. Mario Rustia, an animal pathologist at the Eppley Cancer Institute in Omaha, published the results of tests that he had conducted on mice with Flagyl, a commonly prescribed drug used to treat parasitic infections.

It is now more than a year since New Yorkers voted decisively for sweeping changes in the city charter. Progress or lack of progress toward implementing these changes is the timely topic of a series of State Charter Revision Commission hearings that opened yesterday at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 President Ford's press secretary, Ron Nessen, exploded with anger today while reporters interviewed President-elect Jimmy Carter's chief spokesman, Jody Powell, in the White House press office.

Hartwick, Howard and Clemson won their soccer matches yesterday to reach regional finals in the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs. WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 Housing starts dipped in October but were still at the highest levels in more than two years except for September the Commerce Department reported today.

ANOTHER of those living legends, Herbert von Karajan, concluded his current New York appearances with the Verdi Requiem last night in Carnegie Hall. In the last few days he and the Berlin Philharmonic, with the Vienna Singverein, have been presenting some of the masterpieces of the choral literature, and this was the grand finale.

PARIS This week's Brezhnev-Tito colloquy in Belgrade is a most important dialogue and also one about which little, apart from formal statements, will be known at least for months to come. President Tito, the first man to thumb his nose at Stalin and get away with it, is now 84 and unwell, despite occasional displays of remarkable vitality.

Myron Kartman, violinist, and William Henderson, pianist, who form the Steinerius Duo of the University of Alabama, made a much admired debut in Town Hall five years ago. TRENTON, Nov. 16 (AP) A 55-yearold seamstress from Manhattan, who said she was out of work, won $50,000 a year for 20 years, or $1 million, in the New Jersey Lottery today.

Despite an urgent need for new and better birth control methods, United States public and private support of research on reproductive biology and on contraceptives has been declining since 1972 and is expected to diminish further over the near future, according to a study sponsored chiefly by the Ford Foundation.

Albert M. Kahn, a retired rubber manufacturer, died Monday at a hospital in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Thousand Oaks.

TOKYO, Nov. 16 Japanese steel exports to the United States climbed sharply to 5,655,000 tons during the first nine months, an increase of 44.1 percent from a year earlier, a statistical survey issued by the Japan Iron and Steel Federation showed.

Mars went behind the sun earlier this month, thus interrupting for a time communications between Earth and the instruments landed on the Martian surface by the successful Viking 1 and 2 rockets. The temporary halt in the receipt of new data permits a preliminary evaluation of what has been accomplished since last summer's historic landings.
Drinks were served just after 9 o'clock yesterday morning in the office of Gordon Weaver, vice presidentmarketing of Paramount Pictures. That's show biz.

Robin Roberts, who won 286 games during his major league career and gained membership in the Hall of Fame this year, has been named baseball coach at the University of South Florida in Tampa.

The proposal for a $40 million, 146-acre Staten Island amusement park which for months has pitted Mayor Beame against the angry opposition of hundreds of Staten Island residents and all of their elected representatives was in effect killed last night when the Mayor's representative on the Board of Estimate announced the Mr. Beame would no longer support it.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov. 17 (Reuters) Abdul Hamid Bhashani, a Bengali politician and Moslem leader, died in Dacca's Medical College Hospital tonight. He was believed to be 97 years old. He was admitted to the hospital three weeks ago with a heart condition and acute bronchitis.
HOUSTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally has predicted that President-elect Jimmy Carter will have little success in reorganizing the Federal Government.

The Unilever Group, one of the world's 10 largest industrial enterprises, which controls more than 500 operating subsidiaries, reported yesterday a combined income increase of 29 percent for the third quarter. This continued the recovery in earnings shown in the first two quarters this year, after a fluctuating pattern in the last two years.

A New York scientist who developed a new laboratory tool that has led to discoveries in many fields of medicine, two doctors who developed a drug that is widely used in the treatment of heart disease and high blood pressure, and the World Health Organization, which has virtually eradicated smallpox, were announced yesterday as winners of the 1976 Albert Lasker Awards in medicine.

The British want him in on plans for support of the pound. The New York Mets said last night that Jerry Grote, their No. 1 catcher for 10 years, was "intent on retiring" because of a chronic back ailment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) The career diplomats in the State Department have voted overwhelmingly to oust the president of their professional organization, it was announced today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 17 (AP) Anne-Marie Snellman, a former Associated Press correspondent in Helsinki, died today after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) Rosalynn Carter plans to hold frequent news conferences, will have an active role as a policy adviser and will pursue her interests with the mentally retarded and the problems of the aged in the new Jimmy Carter Administration, her press secretary said today.

DALLAS, Nov. 17 (UPI) Braniff International and British Airways said today that they were negotiating to provide Concorde subsonic flights between Washington and Dallas-Fort Worth as an extension of the Washington-to-London supersonic route.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 Leonid 1, Brezhnev concluded three days of talks with President Tito today, leaving the impression that their two countries were on the closest terms they have been in many years.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 A Federal judge imposed today a three-month prison term on a Greenwich, Conn., man who is the highest ranking grain company executive convicted so far in the continuing investigation of corruption in the grain export industry.

The battle to abolish slavery and the slave trade in the British Empire is the subject of a six-part British Broadcasting Corporation television series, "The Fight Against Slavery," which will first appear in the United States for six consecutive Mondays beginning Nov. 29 at 9 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13. The episodes will be rebroadcast the following Saturday evening.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 The League of Women Voters, which sponsored the Presidential debates has found it is experiencing a postdebate fund-raising problem.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 Toyota said today it was raising 1977 model prices by 2.8 percent, or $100 a car, from 1976 levels but expected to maintain its import leadership with sales of about 390,000 units next year.

STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 17 The Army's choice last week of the Chrysler Corporation as the primary contractor for its proposed new generation of battle tanks may help fuel this hard-hit industrial state's economic recovery 18 to 24 months from now and may help assure relative prosperity for the state in the early 1980's.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 17 A carefully designed study has found no evidence to support the popular contention that a high-fiber diet can prevent heart disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 A Chilean Government decision to release most of its political prisoners was welcomed today by the State Department, which indicated that the United States had played a behind-the-scenes role to bring it about.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (UPI) Top-seeded Jimmy Connors scored a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Marty Riessen today and reached the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Benson and Hedges Grand Prix tennis tournament at Wembley. Connors's 65-minute victory earned him a match against Stan Smith, who crushed Haroon Rahim of Pakistan, 6-1, 6-0.

WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 20 (AP) Jimmy Connors reached the final of a $125,000 Grand Prix tennis tonrnament tonight by defeating Brian Gottfried, 6-3, 5-7, 6-2. In tomorrow's final, Connors will meet Roscoe Tanner, who defeated Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 6-2, 4-6, 7-5 in the other semifinal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) President Ford will put his Alexandria, Va., house up for sale, his press secretary, Ron Nessen, announced today.

THOSE New Jersey gardeners who like to season stews and salads with fresh herbs, as well as garnish drinks with them, can have some of their favorites available the year round by growing them as potted plants indoors.

OFFICIALS in New Jersey are wondering whatever happened to the state's "Bicentennial ghost." Next year will be the 200th anniversay of his death, and it has been almost four years since he came to official attention.

The highest court in New York State has identified the joker in the stack of cards on which New York City's financial recovery plan is built, and thrown it out of the game. The so-called debt "moratorium," the court said, was not the legal product of financial wizardry but simple and unconstitutional avoidance of the obvious: The city owed money to its noteholders and didn't pay it when it was due.

After several seasons of bright colors, largescale patterns and lots of batiks, the freshest fabrics for draperies and slipcovers show geometric Art Deco designs. Variations of the 1930's themes include dots, lines, squiggles and tree-form repeat designs. There's scarcely a hard-edged geometric to be seen. Colors are also Art Deco inspired: There are watery blues and greens, toned-down apricots, mauves and oranges, as well as deep, muted neutral tones such as plum, russet and burgundy.

The golfer breaks away from inertia with a waggle, only to stop all movement for an instant before he goes into his backswing. The baseball player may flap his elbow or twirl his bat, but once the pitcher plants his foot and lets fly, the batter becomes rigid.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 20 Thailand's military junta, which seized power in a coup Oct. 6, today appointed a 340member National Assembly with a broad variety of members from business, the military and politics. Most of the members, however, are from the far right, with more than half being military officers or former officers.

MONTREAL Two French Canadians are to meet next month in one of the more dramatic confrontations in modern Canadian history. Pierre Elliott Trudeau, whose home town is Montreal, is Prime Minister of Canada and is responsible for maintaining its territorial integrity. Rene Levesque, whose home town is also Montreal, is Premier-elect of Quebec after last week's election and he wants to lead his province eventually to independence.

WASHINGTON When the White House is passing from one party to another, the President-elect traditionally uses the process of selecting a Cabinet for much more than assembling the people who will hold top positions in his Administration. WHEN I annually visited Walt Whitman's house at 330 Mickle Street in Camden in the late 1940's and early 1950's, it stood on a narrow, dusty street in a dingy neighborhood. But only one adjoining house was still standing, and the two houses faced a wide, busy boulevard instead of the back street the poet knew.
