TRENTON, Nov. 24 A New YorkNew Jersey joint legislative committee will hear testimony from Federal, state wand regional experts on Dec. 7 to find ways to speed the closing of the Atlan tic Ocean as a dumping ground for raw sewage and sludge.
Ethel Davidson Crystal, a retired elementary-school teacher, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 3980 Orloff Avenue, the Bronx.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) The dollar had a good day on European foreign exchanges today while the price of gold slipped back for the second consecutive trading session.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Nov. 24 Charges against Peter A. Reilly in the murder of his mother were dropped here today after the new States Attorney announced that, he had discovered evidence in the files of his predecessor that tended to clear the youth.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, his position shaken by the overwhelming victory of the separatist party in the Quebec provincial elections last week, appealed to Canadians tonight for a renewal of national unity.
Freederick Morgan Davenport Jr., a retired lawyer, of 1115 Fifth Avenue, New York City, died early Tuesday morning in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home after a lengthy illness. His age was 76.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Nov. 24 Charges against Peter A. Reilly in the murder of his mother were dropped here today after the new State's Attorney announced that he had discovered evidence in the files of his predecessor that tended to clear the youth.

Twenty years ago, Shirley Clambers read a story about Basenjis the barkless dogs and became intrigued. "When I saw an ad for some puppies, I drove to the breeder and left with an 8-weekold red and white, Khajah of Story

Taking what it called an "unprecedented approach to presenting a 'novel for television'." ABC has announced that it will broadcast "Roots" for a total of 12 hours on eight consecutive nights in January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Pentagon said today it would go ahead with the closing or reduction in operations of seven military bases, including the Philadelphia's Frankford Arsenal, which Vice President-elect Walter F. Mondale had promised to keep open. The arsenal will be closed next September.

Tex Antoine, the WABC-TV weather reporter, was suspended indefinitely by station officials last night after he made flippant remark on the air about rape. The 53-year-old broadcaster was accused of "an inexcusable lapse in judgment" by the station officials, who issued an apology for what they called Mr. Antoine's "insensitive and offensive" comment during an evening newscast shortly before 7 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Rhodesia is reportedly building three airfields capable of handling transport planes even as discussions continue in Geneva on proposals to turn over control of the white-ruled nation to its black majority.

Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways received approval yesterday from the State Racing and Wagering board for a combined total of 313 programs in 1977. The board approved 163 nights of racing for Yonkers and 150 nights for Roosevelt. It also granted Monticello Raceway 184 programs.
Two major steelmakers announced yesterday that they would raise the price of sheet steel used by the automobile, appliance and construction industries by about 6 percent on Dec. 1.
GENEVA, Nov. 24 Black nationalist leaders were unable today to agree on a joint response to the latest British effort to find a compromise formula on a date for independence under black rule.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 24 (UPI) Rhodesia has sent its air force into action against Mozambican Government positions in response to what it called "unprovoked aggression" against its troops hunting guerrillas in Rhodesia, the military command announced today.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 24 (AP) A City Court judge ordered the arrest of Jerry Lee Lewis today after the entertainer did not appear in court to answer a drunkenness charge.
Ernest L. Molloy, former director and chief executive officer of R. H. Macy Co. Inc., died Tuesday in San Francisco after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Incline Village, Nev.

The jury at the Harlem mosque trial sat down to its eighth day of deliberations yesterday, and after two jurors said they thought there was still hope of reaching a verdict, the presiding judge ruled that deliberations would continue after a day's recess for Thanksgiving.

People who went out shopping for nuts for their Thanksgiving holiday tables might, have been astonished to see that some prices have soared since last year. If they were curious enough to check into the reasons behind this, they would have found that an unlikely collection of events from turmoil in Africa to bad weather in California all contributed to the higher prices of pecans, walnuts, cashews and other favorite nuts.

Net redemptions of mutual fund shares in October were the lowest since December 1975 as sales exceeded redemptions by $72 million, compared with September's excess of $234.4 million, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

In a low-keyed opening address at the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Nairobi early this month, Ambassador John Reinhardt of the United States made an eloquent plea for halting the politicization of UNESCO and returning the agency to the specialized work implied by its title. The conference has not attained that lofty objective, but it has brought UNESCO part of the way back.
Bianca Leale Cerf, the founder and president of the Petham United Nations Discussion Group, died Monday at New Rochelle Hospital. She was 72 years old and a resident of New Rochelle.

The proposed resumption of helicopter service at the Pan Am Building after a lapse of nearly nine years was pictured alternately at a hearing yesterday as a boon to the city's economy and a noisy hazard to residents and businesses in the Grand Central area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 A proposed change in the conflict-of-interest rules of the bar here, which would limit the shuttling of lawyers in Government agencies to new jobs in Washington law firms that have cases before the agencies, failed to win approval in a test vote last night in the legal ethics committee of the District of Columbia Bar Association. It may still be revived however.

Lorin Hollander set himself an unusual challenge in his recital on Tuesday night at the 92d Street YM-YWHA. He played two piano sonatas by Schubert, the one in G (Op. 78) and the one in B flat (Op. post.). It is the kind of program one might have expected in an earlier age from Artur Schnabel or today from that seasoned veteran Rudolf Serkin.

GENEVA, Nov. 24 (UPI) Swiss authorities today announced the arrest of a man and a woman on charges of working for Soviet espionage agents employed at the International Labor Organization and the Geneva offices of Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline.
PARIS, Nov. 24 Andre Malraux, who died yesterday of lung cancer at the age of 77, was buried today at the cemetery of Verrieres-le-Buisson, not far from Paris.

A few years ago Robert C. Anderson, chairman of the Atlantic Richfield Company, learned that Sinclair Oil was being threatened by an unfriendly takeover attempt. He immediately called the head of Sinclair and told ...

If Rutgers beats Colgate tonight at Giants Stadium and Pittsburgh defeats Penn State tomorrow night in Pittsburgh, it will be the first time since 1940 that two Eastern major college football teams managed to get through the same regular season undeated and untied.
ROME, Nov. 23 (AP)-Prof. Pietro Valdoni, who headed the surgical team that removed Pope Paul VI's prostate gland in 1967, died at his home in Rome early today. He was 76 years old.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 24 (AP) Chile's Roman Catholic Cardinal today received the son of Huber Matos, a political prisoner in Cuba, and said that he would support humanitarian efforts to secure the father's release.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 Federal District Judge David W. Williams has ruled that a California institution must restore to Dr. Alexander Comfort, author of the best-selling "The Joy of Sex," a portion of the royalties it shared with him under a complicated contract that enabled the British physician to collect American profits from the book in dollars instead of English sterling.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 24 A major earthquake struck a mountainous area of eastern Turkey today, and the Government said the death toll could be at least 3,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 Two American writers, long resident in are visited by policemen and told they are being expelled from the country. They are not allowed to know the specific reasons, or the names of their accusers; they have no right to a hearing. They learn only that the authorities suspect them of such things as "disseminating information harmful to the security of" the state.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 Last Thursday, Governor Byrne signed an executive order making the Friday after Thanksgiving a nonwork day for 70,000 state employees. Thousands of those employees made it a five-day weekend by also taking today off. Thousands of others took the afternoon off.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 24 Westchester County communities interested in joining a proposed countywide plan to convert solid waste into gas and electricity will be asked to sign contracts insuring a steady flow of garbage to the plant, County Executive Alfred B. DeBello said today.

Mexico is in the midst of its worst financial panic since the revolution of 1910. The peso, which had been pegged at a rate of 12.5 to the dollar, has lost about half its value: Capital has been fleeing out of pesos into dollars.

Natalie Cole, who opened a six-night run at the Winter Garden Tuesday, is the consummate professional soul-pop singer of the day. She works hard, and she gives demonstrable pleasure to her audiences in a nice range of musical idiom. One feels almost churlish to point out that so far she lacks that ultimate individuality and force of personality that distinguish great stars.
BOONVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 24 (UPI) A weekend of deer hunting in the Adiron dack wilderness ended yesterday in death for one Lewes County youth and shock and frostbite for two others.

Major bank trust departments were clearly not on the same wavelength as the mutual funds in the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1976, according to figures just released in Spectrum, a publication of Computer Directions Advisers Inc., of Silver Spring, Md.

As the canonization of the Cincinnati Reds continues, the "inner conceit," as Johnny Bench calls it, increases on what could he the first National League team to win the World Series three consecutive years. Joe Morgan was named the National League's most valuable player yesterday for the second consecutive year, the fifth time in the last seven seasons that a member of the Reds has been anointed by the baseball writers' panel.
NEWARK Within the Newark Fire Department is a 20-man all-volunteer unit called the Rescue Squad that re sponds to any fire in the city where there is potential danger to life.

Prepared to celebrate whatever they have harvested from the Bicentennial year, Americans will gather around mostly bountiful boards today for the first national day of Thanksgiving since crossing what President Ford called in his holiday proclamation "the treshold into our third century."

Federal epidemiologists intensified yesterday their investigation into an apparent case of swine influenza in Missouri as health departments elsewhere reported an upsurge in demand for swine flu shots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) President Ford today held his first post-election meeting with Senator Robert Dole, his Vice-Presidential nominee, who said they had talked alone about "how we almost put it together" for a victory.

The outlines of a possible plan that would enable New York City to repay the holders of $1 billion in short-term notes without involving the Federal Government were presented yesterday to the city's bankers and union leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of 4,800 jars of maraschino cherries colored with excessive amounts of Red No. 4, which was banned in September as a possible health hazard.
TRENTON, Nov. 24 (AP) An employee who is shunned by her coworkers has good cause to leave her job and may collect unemployment, according to a ruling of the Appellate Division of the Superior Court.

Osian Ellis, the Welsh harpist, was guest of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in its Tuesday concert at Alice Tully Hall (and for the preceding companion event on Sunday afternoon), and he was soloist in three works of different character that added much charm to the program.

West Germany's Franz-Josef Strauss has threatened in the past to end the electoral and parliamentary alliance of his Bavarian-based Christian Social Union with the larger Christian Democratic Union. Now the ambitious former Defense and Finance Minister has broken up the 27-year-old tandem in an action widely interpreted as a last desperate bid to salvage whatever chance he may have to become Chancellor of the Federal Republic.

Bayside and St. Francis won their League football titles on Saturday; today they play for bragging rights. The two Queens schools are trying to establish a neighborhood rivalry with a Thanksgiving Day game.

ROOTS RHYTHMS Since its local advent in 1970, the Ballet Hispanico has presented numerous aspects of the Spanish heritage, from classical flamenco to Latin American folk traditions and street dances of New York, with a growing reputation for its young performers on a national level, under the direction of Tina Ramirez.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which has been criticized and, at times, ridiculed for its vast and growing backlog of complaints, decided this summer what to do about it. It would simply spend less time dealing with the complaints, and, in business parlance, "write down" many of the oldest complaints, which more than likely had been made moot by the passage of time anyway.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 Israeli officials are promoting the idea that the best way to avert a confrontation between Israeli and Syrian forces at the Lebanese border would be the creation of a buffer zone patrolled by Lebanese forces responsible to President Elias Sarkis.

A deputy chief fire marshal said last night that the Fire Department had begun to investigate a report that the American Chicle Company in Long Island City, Queens had been warned in 1975 that its continued use of volatile chemical dust as a gum-machine lubricant could cause an explosion.
A Federal grand jury is investigating trading in the stocks handled by two competing specialist firms on the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

There were thumb-suckers and balkers, absolute hams who waved at the crowd and tried to get back on the runway yelling "Wanna do it again!" Three hundred parents, sisters and brothers, grandmothers and next-door neighbors, armed with Instamatics, jostled to get pictures of Lesie or Jonathan or Jennifer. Flashbulbs popped as fathers called out "Alexis, look over here!" Professional, photographers hardly had a chance.

AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 24 President elect Jimmy Carter will appoint Thomas Bertram Lance, a millionaire Georgia banker, to a Cabinet-level position, but not necessarily director of the Office of Management and Budget, a spokesman said here today.
ATLANTA, Nov. 23 What is the rest of the nation, the non-South, to make of all these Georgians soon to march north?

PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 24 (UPI) The National Bank of Georgia, headed by Mr. Lance, has given loan credit of more than $1 million to Mr. Carter and his family for construction of a peanut Sheller and ... a warehouse, Mr. Carter's office said today.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP) Hidden 29 years in a cavernous hangar, Howard R. Hughes's giant wooden flying boat, the Spruce Goose, is getting a new look from Government officials who say they may try to send it aloft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Jimmy Carter will be unable to gain control of many regulatory agencies for five or six months and, in a few cases, a year or more after he becomes President. The delay will be caused primarily by the time-consuming process of selecting nominees to fill existing vacancies and obtaining their confirmation by the various Senate committees and the full Senate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (Reuters) A moderate earthquake occurred today about 90 to 100 miles east of Bermuda, on the so-called Bermuda rise, the United States Geological Survey reported.

Prepared to celebrate whatever they have harvested from the Bicentennial year, Americans will gather around mostly bountiful boards today for the first national day of Thanksgiving since crossing what President Ford called in his holiday proclamation "the treshold into our third century."

This may be a Thanksgiving in which fewer Americans partake of sweet potato casseroles with marshmallows on top, a dish that has risen to ritual food status over the years and somehow managed to stick there.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24-The director of the Federal Center for Disease Control today defended the Government's investigation of a mysterious disease in Pennsylvania, while acknowledging flaws in the nation's capacity to deal with illnesses caused by toxic chemicals.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 William W. Scranton, the United States delegate, warned third world countries today against what he said were Soviet attempts to manipulate them.

The National Earthquake Information Center in Denver placed the epicenter of the Turkish quake almost directly under Mount Ararat, giving the severity as 7.4 compared with 8.0 for the July 27 quake in the Tangshan area of northern China. The Chinese quake is presumed to have killed tens of thousands, although no official toll has been announced by the Chinese.

PEKING, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Wang Hung-wen, the Shanghai radical once considered a likely successor to Mao Tsetung as leader of the Chinese Communist Party, was accused today in the Peking newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao of stirring up political strife in the southeastern city of Hangchow.

MASHPEE, Mass., Nov. 24 When the Pilgrims sat down to their first Thanksgiving in New England 355 years ago, Massasoit, the leader of the Wampanoag Indians, and 90 of his braves sat among them and provided five deer for the feast. The festival celebrated not only survival through the first harsh winter and the gathering of the harvest, but also the friendship and help of the Indians.

Patti Smith, whos at the Bottom Line for a week-long run through Sunday, is laboring under something of a backlash at the moment, and it's partly her own fault. Originally she was a totally individual art-rocker, who chanted poe try over rock-flavored minimalist accompaniment.

In his two terms as President, Thomas Jefferson refused to issue the annual Thanksgiving Proclamation that had already come to be a Presidential ritual. A reading of the often pompous sermonettes that have over the years emanated from the White House gives some justification for Jefferson's view of such official notices as a "monarchical practice."
TEANECCK, Nov. 24 For members of the Senior Services Center of Teaneck Inc., this Thanksgiving is a special day of gratitude.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) A Civil Aeronautics Board judge ordered Trans World Airlines today to stop calling itself the "on-time airline" and to spend $1.6 million telling the public previous claims to that effect were wrong.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) "Just before sun rise the People mutinied, seizing me while I slept in my Cabin."
DETROIT, Nov. 24 Domestic new car sales remain essentially flat, reports today from the leading automakers for the mid-November period indicated.

MARGAUX, France The colonnade of sycamores slopes gently from the road through acres of vineyards cultivated since days of knights and halberds, and swings round towards a brook and the neo-palladian chateau Pierre Ginestet calls home.

A sniper armed with a pellet gun shot and slighly wounded two women in midtown Manhattan last night, according to the police, who were at the scene invesigating the first shooting when the second shot was fired.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 There was no indication today that Syrian troops in Lebanon were moving closer to the border of Israel from positions they occupied three days ago.

Countess Mary Koutouzow Tolstoy, a leading figure in the American colony in Paris for more than half a century, died in Paris last Senday at the age of 92, according to news received here by United Press International.

The newly reconstituted Board of Higher Education is initiating a publicity campaign to generate public support for keeping $94.3 million that the Beame administration has proposed to cut from next year's budget for the 10 senior colleges of the City University of New York.

Virgil Thomson is 80 years old today, but he does not seem unduly weighed down by age. "We live a long time in my family," the distinguished American composer and critic said cheerily the other day. "My sister's 91. She's in a nursing home now because she broke both legs. We do fall down."
DALLAS The Democratic Ins have 2,200 slots to fill, and the Republican Outs have only one, Curiously, political interest focuses on who shall be the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Government would he required to purchase $6.8 billion worth of metals and raw materials to meet its new objective of establishing a three-year stockpile of strategic materials, the Joint Congressional Committee on Defense Production was told today. Under the new policy, which requires.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Justice Department has attacked on antitrust grounds a major, informal shipping agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union that would bring the fastgrowing Russian fleet into world rate-setting conferences, it was disclosed today.

HAVANA, Nov. 24 (Reuters)-Free calls from public telephones, an early fixture of Premier Fide! Castro's Government come to an end today, the Communications Ministry announced. Local threeminute phone calls will cost 5 cents.

BONN, Nov. 24 A Government-appointed group of economic advisers today submitted a report recommending a $1.25 billion program of tax incentives for West German industry, inexpensive credits for new companies and aid to the unemployed.
J. Stuart Riedel, former general counsel of the New York City Transit Authority, died Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospi tal, Tarrytown, N. Y. He was 67 years old and a resident of White Plains.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 24 Jim Zorn, the Seattle Seahawk quarter back who will face the Giants on Sun day, is left-handed.

The newly reconstituted Board of Higher Education is initiating a publicity campaign to generate public support for keeping $94.3 million that the Beame administration has proposed to cut from next year's budget for the 10 senior colleges of the City University of New York.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia The pattern of life has been changing in this wealthy desert kingdom since King Khalid succeeded his murdered brother, King Faisal, last year. It has grown more complex, more swift, in some ways more harsh.

John E. Zuccotti, New York City's First Deputy Mayor, was reported yesterday by sources at City Hall as being one of those under consideration for Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in President-elect Jimmy Carter's Cabinet.
The California Angels, acting more aggressively with Gene Autry's bank account than Autry ever did on his horse, Champion, signed Bobby Grich last night, filling their quota of three free agents.

The pilgrims keep coming, blemished by jet lag new, but with the same timelessly tight grasp on their possessions and anxious eye for this new place, America. Customs agents seized a cooked chicken with a friendly apology, and some apples, too, but otherwise the group of 49 Soviet Jews who arrived on Alitalia Flight 610 moved into this new land largely unnoticed Tuesday night.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 Starting Saturday, New Jersey telephone users can reduce the cost of their basic monthly service by up to 30 percent simply by going to a business office and asking for a new "lifeline" rate, the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today.
Paul W. Ward, a former Baltimore Sun, reporter who won a Pulitzer Prize for overseas reporting died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 71 years old.

Jennifer Muller's choreographic attention in the last several years has flickered back and forth between neat, formal performing vehicles and untidy "life as art" works. On Tuesday evening at the Roundabout Stage One she presented one of the untidiest works that she has ever given. It was only part of a larger piece but had a sloppy panache that will not easily be forgotten.
American innovation and ingenuity have lost their momentum, the chairman of the President's Committee on Science and Technology told the National Academy of Engineering in Washington last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 George W. Bush announced today that he was resigning as Director of Central Intelligence effective Jan. 20, the day President Ford will leave office.

LONDON, Nov. 24 What started as a vague idea over dinner at a London restaurant 12 days ago became a reality today with the formal announcement that an American oil company, Atlantic Richfield, was acquiring a 90 per cent interest in The Observer, one of Britain's most prestigious, and troubled, newspapers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Soviet police have arrested an American airline employee and charged him with drunken driving and speeding, the United States Embassy said tonight, calling the arrest apparent retaliation for the arrest of a Soviet Aeroflot official in the United States.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) Soybean futures closey today with a gain of 7 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade but most other farm commodity futures were uneven or a shade lower at the close.

Alexander's Inc., a leading New York area retailer, told its shareholders at the annual meeting in Paramus, N. J., yesterday that its net profit in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 23 declined about 25 percent from the year-earlier level.

Corneille's "Rodogune" is an ironhard and beautiful play about the rigorous working-out of a passionate evil. The evil is Cleopatra. Instead of Shakespeare's multifarious creature, she is one whose magic has turned all black as if, instead of killing her, the aspbite had changed her into the asp..

A taxpayer research group has reported that combined state and local taxes in New York State are taking an increasing share of personal income, in addition to continuing the nation's highest tax load in dollars per resident.
GREENWICH, Nov. 24 Details of a tentative agreement between Greenwich's 700 teachers and the school system were disclosed today.

Like a thunderclap, the State Court of Appeals decision invalidating the moratorium on the payment of $1 billion in short-term New York City notes sent all the participants in the city's longrunnine fiscal drama scrambling for cov
The unusually cold weather over most of the nation so far this winter, pushed stocks of home-heating oil down sharply last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
The Orion Capital Corporation of Parsippany, N.J., said yesterday that the company might sell the Northern Life Insurance Company of Seattle, one of its principal assets.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Atlanta Constitution published today a picture of Thomas Bertram Lance, President-elect Jimmy Carter's likely appointee to a high Cabinet-level job, seated in a rocking chair.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 24 Leonid I. Brezhnev today ended three days of talks with Rumanians with a call for unity and cohesion among the Soviet Union and its East European allies.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Britain's Labor Government today declared its determination to nationalize the aircraft and shipbuilding industries despite opposition in Parliament.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 Two young New York experts were among the leaders at the halfway mark in the blue ribbon pair championship of the American contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals at the William Penn Hotel here tonight.
SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 24 (UPI) A judge has told Braniff Airways to begin paying $1.1 million worth of penalties to employees involved in a job discrimination case.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Shoppers who see citizens-band radios offered at big discounts this month should be wary, the Federal Trade Commission says.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 24 A Passaic County Court judge explained on the stand today in the triplemurder retrial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis some of the factors that went into his sentencing of Alfred P. Bello a key prosecution witness, in their trial and in the first murder trial nine years ago.
Stock prices moved generally higher yesterday in stepped-up trading, although the Dow Jones industrial average posted only a modest gain.

Despite the change of administrations in Washington, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. expects to retain his job as chief of the United Staates forces in Europe and the post of NATO Commander General that traditionally goes along with it.

A 16-year-old delivery boy was charged with assault, robbery and rape yesterday in an attack on a 25-year-old East Side woman who was rescued by her husband when he arrived home from work and found the youth menacing his wife with a knife, the police reported.
Two major steelmakers announced yesterday that they would raise the price of sheet steel used by the automobile, appliance and construction industries by about 6 percent on Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 George W. Bush announced today that he was resigning as Director of Central Intelligence affective Jan. 20, the day President Ford will leave office.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 24 A key defense witness in the murder trial of Dr. Charles E. Friedgood testified today that she had spoken to Sophie Friedgood on the telephone eight hours after the prosecution contends that the woman had been killed by her husband.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 Starting Saturday, New Jersey telephone users can reduce the cost of their basic monthly service by up to 30 percent simply by going to a business office and asking for a new a "lifeline" rate, the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Oklahoma City newspapers cannot be barred by a county judge from publishing the name and picture of an 11-year-old boy found delinquent by reason of second-degree manslaughter, the Supreme Court ruled today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 John Davidson offset the sometimes weak play of his teammates at the Spectrum tonight, making 37 saves on shots by the Philadelphia Flyers to preserve a 2-2 tie.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 24 In what was probably his best effort since joining the New York Nets before the beginning of the National Basketball Association season, Nate Archibald drove his team to a 99-91 triumph over a tired San Antonio Spurs club tonight before a lively but sparse crowd of 6,583 at Nassau Coliseum.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association will present Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles with the annual Theodore. Roosevelt award, the N.C.A.A.'s highest honor, at the association's annual luncheon on Jan. 11

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., NOV. 24 The General Assembly formally proclaimed today the right of Palestinian Arab refugees to establish their owm state and to reclaim their former homes and properties in what has become the state of Israel.

Three men pleaded guilty yesterday to killing Thomas Wright, a brother of City Councilman Samuel D. Wright, in a murder-for-hire plot allegedly hatched by Mr. Wright's partner in a Brooklyn checkcashing business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 State Department officials say they are less concerned than Israel that the recent Syrian moves in Lebanon in particular developments in southern Lebanon near the Israeli border pose a serious danger to stability in the area.

Thanksgiving, it so happens, will be a day of quiet for the Viking spacecraft on and around Mars. The motions of the planets have reached a point at which the sun today is directly between Mars and Earth, an alignment known as solar conjunction that produces a blackout of Viking-to-Earth communications.

Radio station WMCA was fined $5,000 earlier this year by the Federal Communications Commission for permitting Barry Gray, the talk-show moderator, to promote Greek tourism without logging his promotional remarks as commercials.
MADRID, Nov. 25 Apparently with Government approval, the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, which is still illegal, plans to hold its first open congress since the end of the civil war next month.

Cowens invoked a rare clause in an athlete's contract and took an unpaid leave of absence of indefinite duration from the Boston Celtics.

Woodbridge broke up a tough defensive battle with a 52-yard drive for a last-quarter touchdown that defeated Edison Township, 7-0, yesterday in Edison before a standing-room crowd of 4,000.

Dr. J. Schoeberg Setzer, a Lutheran minister and practicing psychotherapist, was stabbed to death yesterday in his office in North Babylon, L.I., by one of his patients, according to the Suffolk County police.

WASHINGTON The Carter victory may well be a blessing in disguise for the Republican Party's progressive wing, for it marks the end of eight frustrating years during which party loyalty forced progressives to support a President with whom they were ideologically uncomfortable.

Every magazine publisher certainly has his favorite horror story of a business calamity. If Allen A. Raymond, editor and publisher of Eearly Years, didn't before, he has now. It's entitled, "The Month That the Address Labels Didn't Stick."
HOUSTON, Nov. 25 Apprehensive Mexicans carried hundreds of millions of dollars over the border into Texas before the Central Bank of Mexico moved Monday to curb the flow, according to Texas bankers.

In 1908, four years after the first subway train rumbled under streets of New York City, small bubble-shaped machines began appearing in stations from City Hall to 145th Street. For a penny, the machine would send a stream of salted peanuts or a huge gumball down a chute into a hand cupped under the small opening.
SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) Scores of blackbirds and pigeons fell from their roosts and died today for the second consecutive day, and the state authorities are searching for a cause.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 The United States and Mexico tonight signed a prisoner-exchange treaty that will enable several hundred Americans serving prison terms here to complete their sentences in the United States.

A 19-year-old youth, arrested Wednesday night after a woman told the police that she recognized him as the man who had raped her, was later also charged with the killing of Milagros Otero, 15, nine days ago and with several assaults on women.

LEXINGTQN, Ky., Nov. 25 (UPI) Kentucky's Mines Commissioner, H.N. Kirkpatrick, said today that a meeting would be held next Tuesday at the Scotia coal mine to determine the nature of future investigations into two explosions at the mine that killed 26 persons last March.

The Chinese Acrobats of Taiwan at the Minskoff Theater make up what is easily the most spectacular family show around this weekend. This is a troupe of tumblers, jugglers, acrobats, dancers, trick cyclists, martial-arts experts and musicians, and they are unlike any Western entertainment.

ARGONNE, Ill., Nov. 23 For the last three months earth-moving machines have been slicing away at an ugly hill of coal-mine refuse that has dominated the southwest Illinois village of Staunton for the last 50 years.

The New York City Ballet's holiday offering Wednesday night at the New York State Theater took the form of the season's first performance of "Coppelia," led exuberantly and joyfully by Helgi Tomasson and Patricia McBride.
MADRID, Nov. 25 (UPI) Former Foreign Minister Fernando Maria Castiella of Spain died of a heart attack today. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 25 (AP) Senator George McGovern endorsed Hubert Humphrey of Minnesota for Senate majority leader today, calling him "the logical choice" for the job.

YONKERS, Nov. 25(AP) The owners of 30 Westchester County apartment buildings have been charged with violating state air-pollution codes by using substandard incinerators. Thirteen of the 30 are in Yonkers.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 24 Syria is eager to avoid giving Israel any pretext for military action in southern Lebanon and it wants to deal with the situation there by political and diplomatic means, Damascus sources said today.

CAIRO, Nov. 25 Unrealistic exchange rates, vague investment laws and confusing bureaucracy are preventing significant foreign investment in Egypt, a task force of American businessmen has concluded in a special report presented to the Egyptian Government.

Over a decade later, minorities are still twice as likely as whites not to have jobs. The median family income of blacks is only about 60 percent that of whites. NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 25 The Soviet Union denounced the United States and other Western nations today on the ground that they were "blocking the will of the majority" at the UNESCO conference here by refusing to negotiate on a controversial resolution on the mass media.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau presented to Parliament today a 1973 report charging that a Government-owned chemical company had paid nearly $2 million in kickbacks to foreign customers. He conceded under questioning that there was no record of any action on the matter in the three and a half years since he first heard of it.

Robert H. Dodds, a civil engineer and a senior editor of Engineering NewsRecord, a McGraw-Hill publication, died Thursday at Rosary Hill in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 62 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26 Seventeen countries called today for an international treaty against the taking of hostages.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 President Tito and his aides reaffirmed today that Yugoslavia would never join any "political, military or state community."

Glen Williams was sitting in the St. John's locker room last night with both his thumbs stuck in an ice bucket. Those thumbs had just helped the Redmen pull out a plum of a victory, 79-65 over Brown, in the opener of the second Joe Lapchick Memorial basketball tournament.

ERZURUM, Turkey, Nov. 26 Turkish and foreign efforts to aid victims of the earthquake in eastern Turkey continued to grow today, and informed Turkish sources predicted that the final death toll would be about 4,000.

QUEBEC, Nov. 26 Rene Levesque, Quebecs new separatist Premier, declared today that the Canadian federal system no longer answered his province's aspirations and angrily rejected charges that he sought to return to a form of tribalism.

Any day now the Madison square Garden boxing promoters will announce that Muhammad Ali, who never has been the retiring type, will resume his role as the world heavyweight champion. History The Socialist International, a loose organization of democratic socialist parties from around the world with headquarters in London, was founded in Frankfurt, West Germany, in July 1951, The founders said that they were re-establishing the Labor and Socialist International, which had ceased functioning after the fall of France in World War II.

The trustees of the major pension fund of the teamsters' union have agreed to begin negotiations with the Federal Government concerning the handling and management of the fund's $1.4 billion in assets, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday.

The police said yesterday that they did not know if the two women and a man who were shot early this week at 46th Street and 10th Avenue had been hit by a vigilante determined to clear out the prostitutes and pimps whose presence has incensed residents of the poor neighborhood for many months.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 Army's football team worked out briefly in sweatsuits today, while Navy players were content with a walk in John F. Kennedy Stadium before tomorrow afternoon's 77th game in their interservice rivalry.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 Two players From Philadelphia who were unknown to fans swept to victory here last night in the blue-ribbon pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

CHICAGO Is there a difference between "filthy lucre" and "windfall profits"? Four hundred years. In the ill-informed, little-understood world of Tudor England (1485-1603), the malaise of the day poverty, high prices or underemployment was attributed to the rich, as it is today. The drive for reform in America of 1976 differs little from England of 1576 with darts aimed at the wealthy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26 Edouard Ghorra, the delegate of Lebanon, is eagerly preparing for a long telephone call to the Foreign Ministry in Beirut.

The Armin Corporation announced yesterday that operations of its computed-time, light-emitting diode watch manufacturing subsidiary in Arlington, Tex., have been discontinued. Competitive conditions in the form of lowpriced electronic watches and the continued softness in the light-emitting diode watch sales "made it uneconomical" to continue making such watches, the concern said.

Frank Cohen has delivered nine babies, searched for scores of missing children and survived two major race riots, a station-house corruption purge and the mysterious enmity of a small, deformed, malnourished looking ex-convict who haunts the doorways of upper Broadway and hates the police with passionate intensity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 The Knicks were floored by the Philadelphia 76ers, 114-103, tonight at The Spectrum and Phil Jackson was floored after taking a right cross to the back of the head from George McGinnis. The blow stunned the off-balance Knick forward.
WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 26(UPI) The telephone company has disconnected Santa Claus's phone. It says he was just too popular.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) Soybean and grain futures fell by about 2 to 8 cents in slow post-holiday dealings on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26(AP) A gas line exploded today in Barrientos, a northern, suburb of Mexico City, and spewed flames that killed at least 10 persons, most of them children, the Red Cross reported. Seventy-six people were injured.

AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 26 Thomas Bertram Lance, the first person publicly assured of a Cabinet-level job in President-elect Jimmy Carter's administration, will soon go to Washington to work on "transitional budgetary matters," a Carter spokesman said today. It was a further indication that the millionaire banker may become director of the Office of Management and Budget.

The average rate on overnight loans of Federal funds, the basic short-term interest rate of the money market and the rate most directly under the control of the Federal Reserve, dropped to 4.90 percent in the week ended Wednesday its lowest level in seven months in the wake of the central bank's new easier monetary policy.

WABC-TV officials and a lawyer representing Tex Antoine will meet Monday to discuss the fate of the television weatherman who made what he called a "human error" in an on-the-air remark about what women should do when threatened with rape.

Annie Brannon carried a crumpled tissue in her hand as she walked slowly around her seventh-floor apartment at 515 Fountain Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Occasionally she would stop and stare vacantly, but she said little to the two dozen relatives and neighbors who had gathered to mourn the death of her 15-year-old son, Randolph Evans.

According to the Random House Dictionary of the English Language college edition, a polonaise is "a slow dance of Polish origin, in triple meter, consisting chiefly of a march or promenade in couples." And that's a fair, if superficial, description of Piers Paul Read's sixth novel. He is also the author of "Alive: The Story of the Andes Survivors," which probably sold more copies than all of his intelligent fictions put together.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 26 A brother-inlaw of Mel Patrick Lynch, one of the two men on trial for the alleged kidnapping of Samuel Bronfman 2d in August 1975, corroborated today the defendant's testimony that Mr. Lynch received a telephone call from someone named "Sam" a year before the alleged abduction.
Energy-related issues helped send stock prices higher yesterday as the market advanced on a broad front in reduced semiholiday trading.

For the second time in less than a year, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has gone to court to try to force local officials to carry out one of the 28 transportation control "strategies" that the city and state themselves proposed more than three years ago.
LIVINGSTON, Nov. 26 New Jersey will have its first specially constructed medical unit for victims of severe burns within 90 days, officials of St. Barnabas Medical Center said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 The Xerox Corporation published this week in the Offical Gazette of the Patent and Trademark Office a long list of American and foreign patents offered for license under a consent order reached with the Federal Trade Commission on July 29, 1975.

Two teen-age girls were shot in a usually quiet section of Bellerose, Queens, by a young man early this morning, the police reported. One girl was later described by the police as in critical condition and the other as in serious condition in Long Island Jewish Hospital.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 26 Just a little bit of luck can go a long way toward helping a good football team keep alive a long winning streak.

A New York contractor and designer believes his extrudable plastic construction forms promise mass housing without the need for skilled labor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) John J. McFall, the majority whip in the House of Representatives, said today that he received $1,000 in cash from the South Korean businessman Park Tong Sun in 1972 in addition to the $3,000 he earlier reported receiving from Mr. Park in 1974.
Lloyd Griffin, chairman of the executive committee of Peters Griffin Woodward Inc. a television sales concern, died Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

Doug Henning, the most exciting magician since Houdini, doesn't look at all like a sorcerer. At age 29 he looks like a flower child in his sneakers and jeans, with his rippling hair, floppy mustache and bright, amazed eyes. He is short and so skinny that Walter Kerr thought at first glance that he had been sawed in half vertically.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 26 At long last the Atlanta Hawks won a game on the road. After 28 successive setbacks away from the Omni in Atlanta (seven this season), the Hawks posted a 109105 victory over the New York Nets tonight. John Drew, with 33 points, led their offense before a crowd of 7,269 at Nassau Coliseum.

HONG KONG, Nov. 26 There are indications that Chiao Kuan-hua, China's urbane Foreign Minister, may be the latest victim of the spreading campaign against Chiang Ching, Mao Tse-tung's widow, and three other disgraced members of the Politburo.

Opponents of a new Federal interstate highway along Manhattan's West Side Westway have argued that the proposed artery could increase air, noise and visual pollution in adjoining neighborhoods. If these environmental problems are their real concern, it is difficult to understand why these same Westway foes have now gone to court to try to block demolition of the crumbling old West Side Highway, which they say they want rebuilt.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 26 Gov. Ella T. Grasso today ordered a new investigation into the 1973 murder of Barbara Gibbons and requested an inquiry into the prosecution of murder charges against Mrs. Gibbons's son, Peter A. Reilly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed today that bureau agents had wounded at least two and perhaps three fellow agents with shotgun fire in a stakeout that thwarted an attempted bank robbery in New Jersey. But a spokesman said that some of the wounds might have been caused by ricochets.

BINGO Muggs that's the name is a pleasant drop-in tavern on the night scene along upper First Avenue, with informal atmosphere, spic-andspan rustic decor and bracing music from Marty Tocci's keyboard. Outside, near 62d Street, there's a brightly lighted banner over a compact dining veranda with hanging plants. It's even more cheerful inside, as you perch at the bar amid yellow lamps and wood paneling that widens into a rear table area.

GENEVA, Nov. 26 The deadlock that has prevailed at the month-long conference on Rhodesia's future was overcome tonight when two black nationalist holdouts accepted a British formula fixing March 1, 1978, as the date for independence under black control.

The New York State Lottery director, John D. Quinn, announced winning numbers last night for the Colossal Year-End Bonus Drawing, with a $980,000 top prize, and for the Holiday Lottery.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 26 The prosecution in the triple-murder retrial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis today continued its effort to bolster the testimony of its key witness, Alfred P. Bello, with corroborative testimony from other witnesses.

LONDON, Nov. 26 Sheikh Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Petroleum Minister, warned the West today against trying to counter Arab oil embargoes with any oil-sharing plan. This he said could "lead to the destruction of everyone."

BRUSSELS, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Unemployment is increasing again among European Economic Community nations notably in West Germany, France, Bel gium and Denmark after falling slightly during the summer, according to the figures released today by the European Economic Community Commission.

Mr. Charles L. Fox Jr., a professor of Surgery at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, was granted Patent 3,993,750 this week for a solution to be injected in seriously burned patients or those recovering from surgery or injuries. It is a blood fluid or plasma substitute designed to compensate for sodium loss.
Alaina Reed has touched most of the bases on the local cabaret circuit, she has toured in "Hair" and has gone as far a field as Australia in "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band on the Road."

Henry Delafield Phelps, an investment banker in Providence, R.I., one of the last surviving members of Newport society's Old Guard, died Thursday at Newport Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at Sunnyfield in Middletown, R.I., which adjoins Newport.
John N. Allman, vice president of the insurance firm of Marsh McLennan of 1221 Avenue of the Americas, died in Chappaqua, N.Y., on Thursday. He was 48 years old.

The things you can rent these days! You can rent a butler, a car, an island, a tuxedo, a painting, a policeman, a six-course dinner for 30. NEWARK, Nov. 26 Two years ago, Arthur was found guilty of breaking and entering, and faced time in a juvenile detention center. Instead, the authorities referred him to the New Ark School here, and the 15-year-old youth says the experience "has made me want to be somebody, to do something."

A portable sleep inducer has a speaker that sits under the pillow and emits a pleasant sound, in tone and strength selected by the user. Trademarked Sleep-a-Tone, the equipment is delivered in a case that will fit in a handbag.

In the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday, Ann Pinckney Proctor Sperber, a member of the public relations staff at Sears, Roebuck Company, was married to Thomas James McKee, who is a lawyer with Colt Industries. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren performed the ceremony.

If the strategic approach of three of the best performing mutual funds is any criterion, making money in the stock market these days means concentrating on such traditional basics as under-valued earnings, clean balance sheets, liquidity, and conservative management.

The Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it would attempt to identify the so-called "boarder babies" in hospitals in New York City so that renewed attempts could be made to place them in appropriate rehabilitative programs and institutions.

TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP) Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Sue Barker of Britain won semifinal matches today in a $100,000 international tennis tournament and will in the final on Sunday, Miss Evert defeated Rosemary Casals of Sausalito, Calif., 6-3, 6-1, and Miss Barker overcame Martina Navratilova, self-exiled Czechoslovak, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2.

EAST BERLIN, Nov. 26 The Dow Chemical Company, a pioneer in trade with Eastern Europe, has entered a new market in East Germany with a longterm agreement with this Communist country. As in most pioneer work, the beginning has not been easy for Dow, the first American company to set up an office in East Berlin, or for Robert Marshall, the company's 30-year-old representative, who is from Baltimore.

FAIR LAWN, Nov. 26 The chill of late autumn fills the rooms of the 18thcentury farmhouse of dull maroon sandstone and wooden shingles. Outside, an 1810 black kettle hangs suspended from a tilted tripod. Out back, the worn brown siding boards of the carriage house are curling from the ravages of 200 years of wind, rain and sun. The aging cherry tree still towers above the henhouse, its black branches stark against the sky.

Many otherwise sensitive persons in late 20th-century America wear the skins of tortured animals. While the most popular fur is mink, which is usually ranch-grown under relatively humane conditions, approximately one-half of all furs sold are derived from raccoon, lynx, fox, squirrel and other wild animals.

LONDON, Nov. 26 The Confederation of British Industry came out unexpectedly today against the harsh deflationary measures that the Government is expected to take soon so as to qualify for a loan from the International Monetary Fund.

Two police officers who broke up a store looting in the Bronx last night stumbled onto a cache of drugs and arms in a bar where the three alleged looters, including the store's security guard, were arrested. The loot included 10 ounces of cocaine with an estimated street value of up to $10,000, 10 ounces of marijuana, a machine gun and a shotgun.

The 21 second-graders at the Aspen Elementary School have a new parttime French teacher. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 In observance of Yugoslavia's national day on Monday, President Tito has granted the customary holiday amnesty to several hundred prisoners. Under this year's amnesty decree, 532 prisoners are to have their sentences reduced, and 163 are to receive pardons.

The American Paper Institute acknowledged yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the Department of Justice in connection with a grand jury Investigation of possible price fixing in the industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) President Ford raised import duties on some European brandies today in the latest round of a trade dispute between the United States and the Common Market. The duty increases partially restored tariff levels reduced in 1974. But the increases were less than some American farm groups had been demanding and left levies on some European brandies untouched.
The private class-action lawsuits growing out of the Equity Funding scandal are about to be settled for $50 million to $60 million, the New York Law Journal reported yesterday.

TRENTON, Nov. 26 The State Labor and Industry Department says that while the recession has hit New Jersey the hardest among the states, the economic damage may not be as severe as statistics indicate.
MONROE, La., Nov. 27 (AP) One of 24 high school football players burned by lime during a playoff game in Gonzales was hospitalized here today with first and second degree burns.

COMMUTER trains still stop at the Oradell station, but most people who go inside these days aren't buying tickets. Three years ago, four women leased the station from the Bergen County town and turned it into the Cricket Gift Shop.
TORONTO, Nov. 27 (AP) Tomorrow's Grey Cup game for the championship of Canadian football will be a rough one for announcers, for fans listening to he game and for everyone who asks: "Who won?"

Lisa Thomas Pickering and David Middlebrook Knight were married yesterday evening in the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Nathan Adams. A reception was held at the Greenwich Country Club.

NEWTON, Mass., NOV. 27 (AP) Glen Capriola ran for 179 yards and two touchdowns in his intercollegiate football farewell today as Boston College trounced Holy Cross, 59-6, in New England's traditional season finale.

It was New York's first shutout victory this season.

The first specific blood test to detect ehronic alcoholism has been developed by a team of researchers here as an unexpected dividend from their alcohol experiments on baboons. The test offers the potential of more precise and improved therapy for the millions of Americans who suffer from alcoholism, a major public health problem, the researchers reported in a scientific journal published yesterday.

AN eye-screening program for all Newark youngsters between the ages of 3 and 5 is to begin next Saturday in an effort to detect such serious vision problems as amblyopia, or "lazy eye." David E. Breinig, who was president of the Breinig Paint Company in Hoboken, N.J., when he retired about 25 years ago, died Wednesday at a convalescent home in Killingly, Conn. His grandfather founded the paint company, which has been merged with a larger company, in 1876.

BRUSSELS, No.29 (UPI) The United States dollar held its own in slow trading on foreign-exchange markets today. The pound was unchanged against the dollar but fell against European currencies. WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 After 108 years, the Thaddeus Stevens School was suddenly fashionable today. One community group wanted all the students to come to trim its Christmas tree. A salesman for My Weekly Reader offered them all free subscriptions.

In the last week, changes in ownership were announced for three famous journals in the English-speaking world. These changes were hopeful auguries, for in each instance fresh financial strength was brought to the aid of publications whose existence has been threatened by real or potential deficits.

A new state law legalizing slowspeed motorcycles and motor-bicycles for the first time goes into effect tomorrow with the State Department of Motor Vehicles already trying to put the brakes on the program.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 29 (Reuters) An Indian railway clerk who founded a mysterious religious sect was sentenced to life imprisonment today for murdering six defectors from his movement.
Benjamin Fletcher Wright, an authority on constitutional law and the fifth president of Smith College, died Sunday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 The Supreme Court agreed today to hear former President Richard M. Nixon's challenge to the 1974 statute that gave the Government control over his Presidential papers and tape recordings.

KATHEKANI, Kenya, Nov. 29 (UPI) At least 12 people were reported killed early today when an exppress train ran onto a flooded bridge whose rails had been swept away, crashed through it and plunged into a river.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP) The prosecutor in the trial of Wendy Yoshimura, once Patricia Hearst's companion as a fugitive, said today that he would show the jury "a frightening arsenal" of weapons found in a Berkeley garage in 1972.

PARIS, Nov. 29 In France they have names like Fifi and Regina. In Canada one is called Candide. In the United States they are known more by the institutions that created them such as the Wharton School or D.R.I. for Data Resources Inc.

A 31-year-old woman was critically wounded in an alleged knife attack by her husband yesterday afternoon in an anteroom of Family Court in Manhattan, where they and an 8-year-old son had gone for a hearing on abuse charges against the father.

MAPUTO, Mozambique, Nov. 24 While delegates in Geneva continue their efforts to devise a peaceful settlement for Rhodesia, the people of this former Portuguese colony are being prepared by their Marxist government for an expanded war.

WASHINGTON, Nov.29 The Supreme Court refused today to review, at least for the time being, the sweeping citysuburban school desegregation plan imposed on the Wilmington, Del., area last spring by a three-judge Federal court.

PITTSBURGH, Nov.29 A powerful Texas-California sextet captured the Reisinger board-a-match team championship here late last night, concluding the Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League.

Brian Kelley is feeling fine, but the Giants' linebacker wonders how long anyone can stay healthy at the House of Wounded Knees.
Periodic changes in the earth's orbit around the sun have been identified as the "fundamental cause" of the ice ages, a team of American and British scientists reported yesterday.

CBS has that kind of hour at 10 o'clock this evening. Starring an 80-year-old master of every trick in show business, it is called "The George Burns Special."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration proposed today an end to the use of chloroform in animal drugs, such as liniments, five months after it ordered the suspected cause of cancer removed from human drugs and cosmetics.
Needham, Harper Steers, the country's 17th largest advertising agency, is the latest to become disenchanted with its publicly held status. Yesterday it announced plans to go private.

The appointment of Edward Klein as editor of The New York Times Magazine was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, managing editor. Mr. Klein, an assistant managing editor of Newsweek magazine, will join The Times around the beginning of the year.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 Proposals that Rhodesian whites be allowed to control the army and the police during the transition to black majority rule were rejected here today by two black nationalist leaders.
Guess what's making everybody sit up and take notice? The recliner.
Is college worth the time, the money and the effort? This question is being asked more and more these days, and the answer is not always in the affirmative.

TRENTON, Nov. 30 Insurance agents criticized today the State Department of Insurance as "inflexible" for hewing to a prior-approval system of rate setting instead of allowing New Jersey's automobile insurance industry to compete in an open-rating system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Federal Energy Administration suggested today that exporting to Japan crude oil produced on the North Slope of Alaska might increase the likelihood of "politically motivated production cutbacks" by Arab oil states, cutbacks aimed at the United States.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) British Cabinet ministers were warned today against leakinginformation to journalists or other politicians when their views were disputed by colleagues.
PALATES sated with turkey might be revived this week with a gambol in lamb by market investors who can ac cept the theory of relativity in bargains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Leading spokesmen for the Democratic and Republican viewpoints on the economy took markedly different views today of the meaning of the latest series of price increases on important industrial products.

ATLANTA, Nov. 30 John Davidson, the Ranger goalie, survived a 16-shot effort by the Atlanta Flames during a scoreless third period tonight and preserved a 2-2 tie with the team New York must pass to latch onto third place and an eventual playoff berth in the Patrick Division. Davidson faced a total of 44 shots in the National Hockey league game.
PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 30 (AP) The president of a major steel company proposed today that industry leaders meet with President-elect Jimmy Carter to discuss recent steel price increases.

The Federal Power Commission announced late yesterday that higher natural gas prices, tentatively approved more than a month ago, could go into effect today. The F.P.C. delayed its final decision until it was convinced by filings by gas producers that the increases would stay within estimates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Supreme Court became further embroiled today in the tangled aftermath of its July 2 rulings on the death penalty and, for the second day in a row, the Court itself added to the confusion.

Call it British pluck. Call it courage under fire. In the face of the highest unemployment in Britain since the Depression and in the shadow of the 45 percent depreciation of the pound in the last five years, a caviar bar has opened in London.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 30 The sixweek-old Bronfman kidnapping trial recessed two hours early today for lack of evidence to present to the jury, and it appears to be drawing to a close with more of the peculiar twists that have marked the case.

The seventh chess Olympiad for women in Haifa, Israel, was won decisively by the Israeli team, Alla Kushnir, Luba Kristol, Olga Podrajanskaya and Lea Nudelman, who scored 17-4 in the eight-team round-robin championship finals.
A spokesman at the Spanish Consulate in New York said this week that she had received many calls from Spaniards visiting or resident here seeking information about the forthcoming voting.

This is the silly season in the wine world, the time of the beaujolais nouveau. This is bland new wine, wine of the 1976 vintage, only partly fermented and packed off to the winedrinking capitals of the world within hours of the deadline imposed by the French Government for its release midnight, Nov. 15.

Dr. Martha Wolfenstein, a professor of psychiatry at the Yeshiva University Albert Einstein College of Medicine and a specialist in child psychology, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 333 Central Park West.

The disorganized Knicks absorbed their fourth straight loss last night and their fifth in the last six games while the guard-oriented Nets obtained the front-court offensive help they had been seeking.
WIMBLEDON, England, Nov. 30 (AP) The All-England Tennis Club announced today a large increase in prize money for the 1977 Wimbledon tournament and settled its quarrel with the women stars.

SADDLE BROOK, Nov. 30 Engineers and managers for 24 chemical plants around the state gathered today in the first of 660 workshops and conferences to be held by the Federal Energy Administration throughout the country in the next year under a $3 million educational program to cut into the waste of energy in industrial and commercial operations.
The only undeveloped land in New York City owned by the Starrett Housing Corporation is a parking lot that occupies the entire west blockfront on Eighth Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets.

New York's latest fiscal crisis could not have struck at a less opportune time. Immobilization in Washington caused by the change in Administrations compels the city to fall back on its own overburdened resources to meet an unforeseen $1 billion obligation that would be staggering in the best of times.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 30 Vincent J. DeSimone Jr., who headed the investigation of the Lafayette Grill triple murders in 1966, told a grand jury, 12 days after the shootings, that the clothing worn by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis on the night in question did not fit the descriptions of the killers' clothing he hd received from witnesses.

Mayor Beame and Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd last night presented certificates of appreciation to members of the force and to civilians in connection with an incident in Harlem last July 31 in which police officers were injured in a lye-throwing attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 A senior officer of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency here has defied orders to return home and is "voluntarily cooperating" with a Federal investigation into alleged Korean bribery of members of Congress, Government investigators said today.

Butch Seewagen, the 30-year-old Columbia coach who stays in competi- tion despite a potentially crippling hip ailment, and Lindsey Beaven, a Priton who found a new home here, have been ranked No. 1 for 1977 by the Eastern Tennis Association.

DRAPER, Utah, Nov. 30 The Utah Board of Pardons today granted Gary Mark Gilmore's plea that he be executed. By a 2-to-1 vote, the board sent the case back to trial Judge J. Robert Bul- lock of Provo to reset the time for the firing squad execution of the 35-year-old convict, who has resisted every effort to delay his death.

NBC-TV has canceled the long-running daytime serial, "Somerset," and will replace it on Jan. 3 with a new soap opera, "Lovers and Friends." "Somerset" went on the air in 1970 as a spinoff of another NBC daytime drama. "Another World."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 A senior officer of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency here has defied orders to return home and is "voluntarily cooperating" with a Federal investigation into alleged Korean bribery of members of Congress, Government investigators said today.

A police officer who had never fired his gun on duty in eight years on the force and who officials said had shown no behavioral problems was indicted yesterday on a second-degree murder charge in the shooting of a 15-year-old Brooklyn boy on Thanksgiving night.
In an effort to fight prostitution in midtown Manhattan, the Police Department is distributing circulars urging prostitutes to break away from their pimps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The White House budget office is seeking to cut the Pentagon's tentative budget request for the coming fiscal year from $128 billion to $121 billion, according to Administration officials.
TRENTON, Nov.30 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state and local governments were not obliged to overcome past racial discrimination by setting up racial quotas in hiring.

The young man with the long red hair and a large orange cat purring on his shoulder, sitting on an orange velvet couch, brought to mind faint recollections of a record jacket one had seen somewhere before. He is 17 years old just a few years younger than his mother was when she started playing her guitar and singing folk songs in Chicago coffee houses, back in the 1960's.

Hear America First opened its 1976-77 season in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on Monday night with a program entitled "The Plucked String." The strings that were plucked during the evening were those of piano, harpsichord, harp, guitar and banjo.
It didn't take the New York Yankees long to pierce the strangest myth on the long-green sports scene that, given their choice, ballplayers would not necessarily rush toward the money.

They also made it clear that they considered United States intentions crucial to their plans.
Mayor Beame yesterday hailed plans for the construction of a $4.5 million Jewish cultural complex in the Lincoln Center area on West 67th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

FEW Christmas gifts bear so personal and generous a message as food; few say so directly that the donor strives to provide pleasure and delight for the recipient. That old Victorian sentiment "Love the giver," expressed traditionally on the tiny, porcelain Battersea boxes, is perhaps even better stated with a delectable morsel meant solely to delight the receiver. To express such sentiment, the food given must be the best available.
CONSUMER groups crusading against utility-rate increases have for years been painting the Consolidated Edison Company as a bank with a generator front, and now the stereotype has finally come true.

THE calendars produced for 1977's children are so clever that the illustrations become everything, while the days of the week are mere supernumeraries, hanging around in case anyone actually wants to know the date.

A white Rolls-Royce glides down the street, leaving a trail of gawking pedestrians in its wake and putting all other cars to shame. In the spacious rear seat, passengers sip champagne and nibble caviar, chopped eggs and sour cream on pumpernickel while their uniformed chauffeur guides the practically noiseless machine through midtown traffic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy was flat in October after declining in the two preceding months, the Commerce Department reported today.

William F. Rickenbacker, son of the late World War I flying ace Eddie Rickenbacker, was injured yesterday when the single-engine Cessna 210 he was piloting crashed on takeoff at Westchester County Airport in White Plains. The 48-year-old son of the hero of World Wars I and II was taken to Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, where he was reported in fair condition with several broken ribs, back burns, and facial lacerations.
LAREDO, Tex., Nov. 29 Vicente Garza's cluttered general store next to the Mexican border bridge used to sell more Tide detergent, Pet milk and Kool-Aid than any other store in the United States.

Eamon Kelly is an Irish storyteller who heard stories from "those old lads," his father and his father's friends sitting around a peat fire in Ireland. More than a million American women have been added to the nation's labor force this year. For many the transition from kitchen to job has brought not only additional money to the household but new satisfaction from life as well.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 Top executives of the Summa Corporation, the late Howard Hughes's holding company, have been told by Chester C. Davis, the concern's chief counsel, that he plans to try to probate an unsigned Hughes will that would change the present direction of the company's control.

The Health Department yesterday announced the names of seven more restaurants charged with having violated the health code. If the reported violations are not corrected by the time of a final inspection, the places are subject to closing. The establishments and the dispositions followed:
NEWARK, Del., Dec. 1 (AP) At least 20 persons were injured today in an explosion, apparently caused by leaking gas, at a crowded fast-food restaurant here, the police said.
TRENTON, Dec. 1 Assemblyman Ronald Owens, Democrat of Newark, was sworn in today as Acting Governor, the second black in the state's history to hold the office.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 The Government does too much, and it does too little. It is loath to harm particular interests, and it ends up harming all. Its processes are hemmed in by rules to prevent abuse of power, and the result is to increase centralized decision-making.

The Washington Capitals, who had easily handled the New York Rangers during their last visit to Madison Square Garden, could find no weak points last night in the suddenly surging New York team and lost, 4-1.

A postal service mailman was slightly injured yesterday when a small incendiary device ignited at a mailbox across from Grand Central Terminal. It was one of four such letter bombs discovered in midtown Manhattan during the day.

Muriel Siebert, president of Muriel Siebert Company, a Wall Street broker who began cutting commissions to small investors by 50 percent last September, has a date with the Justice Department tomorrow.

Like a sleek new tower rising on quicksand, Christopher Boomis's budding realestate empire has come tumbling down. Beame's 1973 mayoral campaign, allegedly in exchange for help in getting a lucrative building project.
WARSAW, Dec. 1 (Reuters) Poland announced today that it was forced to cut back on investment for economic development as a result of expenditures on food imports.

LITTLE ROCK, Dec. 1 (AP) George Earnshaw, a 20-game winner for the Philadelphia Athletics for three straight years, died today at a Little Rock hospital at the age of 76. He had lived in Hot Springs, Ark., since 1952.
MASERU, Lesotho, Dec. 1(AP) Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President, said today that he was denied a visa to South Africa after one had been promised two days ago.

A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a 12-count perjury indictment against former Justice Joseph A. Brust and, in a scathing review of the methods used to obtain the indictment, criticized prosecutors generally for being overzealous.

Leonid M. Tichvinsky, who retired in 1966 as director of the University of Cal ifornia's Student Center at G ttingen, West Germany, died of pneumonia yesterday in St. Mary's Health Center, St. Louis. His age was 79.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Navy and Defense Department research officials are pressing for a decision early next month on the controversial cruise missile program that could cause complications for the Carter Administration in future strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union.

Ten elderly former teachers who lost their jobs in the 1950's for refusing to answer questions about their political beliefs during the McCarthy era were reinstated yesterday by the New York City Board of Education. One of the teachers was reinstated posthumously.

Victor Gotbaum, the head of the largest public-employee union in New York City, said yesterday that the municipal unions would participate in "an overall solution" to the city's latest fiscal crisis only if it included Federal help now.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 1 (AP) Toledo University's Rockets, led by Stan Joplin's 21 points and a tenacious team defense, edged Indiana Universiy, 5957, in basketball tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Defense Department, as part of a reduction in its research budget, has decided to stop Air Force development of a new military transport, industry sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Aviationindustry officials told the Administration today that airline service could suffer severe setbacks if new rules for quieting planes were not supplemented by a system for helping carriers finance the costs.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 Three major retailers in Newark Two Guys, Bamberger's and Hahne's will challenge on Friday in Municipal Court here New Jersey's "blue law" forbidding Sunday sales of certain items.

A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a 12-count perjury indictment against former justice Joseph A. Brust and, in a scathing review of the methods used to obtain the indictment, criticized prosecutors generally for being overzealous.
CHICAGO. Dec. 1 (AP) Grain and soybeans futures traded in mostly higher ranges early on the Chicago Board of Trade today, but late profit taking produced generally uneven price closes.

For better or worse, Britain's Labor Government has crossed the Rubicon on "devolution" for the United Kingdom. It has presented to Parliament a bill 116 pages long, providing for establishment of legislative assembles for Scotland and Wales and the surrender by Westminster of extensive powers to both. In all probability there can be no turning back from the most important constitutional change proposed for Britain in this century.

ST. PAUL. Dec. 2(UPI) A Federal judge granted today the request of the University of Minnesota for a temporary injunction against a probation on the school's teams imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
