"Quarterbacks need more time to learn the plays and the defenses," he was saying the other day. "But being a running back, you do things by instinct. I could see myself as rookie of the year next season. Pro football has always been a dream of mine."
CHICAGO, Dec.3 (AP) Soybean futures gained 12 cents a bushel today and strongly influenced higher prices in other pits on the floor.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3 Arab negotiators intend to start talks on a Middle East settlement next year with a proposal for a Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip, territories occupied by Israel since the war of 1967.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 It seemed inevitable to the foreign policy world that President-elect Carter would select Cyrus Roberts Vance to be his Secretary of State. Among those who were consulted, everyone respected him and no one opposed him.

PARIS, Dec. 3 The first European reaction to the designation of Cyrus R. Vance to be Secretary of State in the Carter administation was one of warm satisfaction. Word reached here after offices were closed, but officials available for comment expressed considerable relief to hear that they would be dealing with a man they knew who had a solid background in European affairs.

Around 2 A.M., Wednesday, Nov. 3, a television commentator speculated, along with millions of others, where Jimmy Carter would pick up the remaining few electoral votes he needed to give him the necessary 270: "Watch Mississippi." Indeed, that state finally went to Mr. Carter, as did Hawaii, and he was projected the winner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) Some imported shipments of an inexpensive blowup toy called Blobo Bubb-A-Loons have been found to contain a hazardous chemical and will be removed from the United States market.

With a robber's shotgun pointed at his head, a 41-year-old former policeman feigned compliance with an order to remove his pants, but drew a revolver from an ankle holster and shot the gunman twice in the head early yesterday during a holdup in a Bronx bar.

ATLANTA, Dec. 3 (AP) Eric Vail shoved a rebound past the Boston goalie, Gilles Gilbert, late in the third period tonight, gaining a 3-1 victory for the Atlanta Flames in a National Hockey League game. Atlanta now has lost only two of its last 14 games.

TRENTON, Dec. 3 After two years of working with private programs, housing officials here believe they have developed the programs that will bring together the concerted efforts of state and local governments, as well as the private sector, to help end the decay of housing in innercity neighborhoods.

GENEVA, Dec. 3 A feeling is growing among black nationalist delegates to the conference on majority rule in Rhodesia and interested parties not sitting at the conference table that only the United States can turn the present talks into a genuine negotiation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 President-elect Jimmy Carter responded today to an appeal by Leonid I. Brezhnev and promised that he would move "aggressively" to get deadlocked negotiations for a new treaty curbing strategic arms "off dead center."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The Supreme Court indefinitely postponed today the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore to give itself more time to consider his case. Mr. Gilmore was to have died before a firing squad in Utah at sunrise on Monday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Dec. 4 President Park Chung Hee abruptly dismissed the head of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency today. Replacing Shin Jik Soo as the head of the politically powerful agency is Construction Minister Kim Jae Kyu, a moderate confidant of the President.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3 A draft treaty that would seek to outlaw manipulation of the environment for military or hostile purposes, was approved today by the General Assembly's Political Committee.
TEHRAN, Iran, Dec. 3 (UPI) Iran won the 10th Aryamhr international freestyle wrestling championships today for the 10th time, with the Soviet Union finishing second, also for the 10th time.
WEST BERLLN, Dec. 3 West Germany has reportedly agreed to pay millions of dollars to East Germany to obtain freedom for several hundred political prisoners by Christmas.

Sales of New York City's largest retailers were virtually flat in November, rising an average 1.9 percent from the yearearlier levels after having achieved their best monthly increase of the year in October.

The Bee Gee's lush string arrangements, sweet harmony vocals and lyrics devoted to teen-age love were anomalies in the late 1960's, when the group began making hit records. Now that the middle of the road has lost some of its 60's stigma, the group is back, and although its newer records sound more like disco than like adolescent pop, the teen appeal remains intact.
BOSTON, Dec. 3 An "adult entertainment district" established by city officials here two years ago has become the object of heated controversy and the subject of a sudden, swift police crackdown.
A firm tone, reflecting a new sense of optimism in Wall Street, prevailed in the stock market yesterday as the broad list of issues performed better than the popular Dow Jones industrial average.

BRUSSELS Jimmy Carter's designation of Cyrus Vance as the next United States Secretary of State is taken as an excellent sign by Western Europe. Although it has been successively dazzled, amused and occasionally bewildered by Henry Kissinger's diplomatic brilliance, it has not always been thoroughly convinced of the good doctor's benevolent intentions to the cause of European unity.

Our Children's Center at New York City Community College in Brooklyn has refused to close its doors although the Agency for Child Development announced last winter that the day-care center was among the 28 it would no longer fund.

A 29-year-old insurance broker was sentenced to three years in jail yesterday for draft evasion despite the defense's reminder that President-elect Jimmy Carter had promised he would pardon all violators of Selective Service laws.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Dec. 3 (AP) In a move hailed by Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe as a states' rights landmark, the Federal Government consented yesterday to an agreement giving state reclamation standards for coal mining on Federal lands precedence over conflicting Federal standards.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) Big American banks are leading a return to Lebanon by the international banking community. As hopes rise of permanent peace there after 19 months of civil war, the bankers have decided it is safe to go back to Beirut, set up business again and count the costs.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 Moving swiftly in an attempt to ease a tense racial situation at its Camp Pendleton base south of here, the Marine Corps last night arrested the leader of the Ku Klux Klan at the base and today flew him to a new base on the East Coast.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 3 El Al, the Israeli national airline, will begin low-budget charter flights its first from Boston to Jerusalem next September.

A former country doctor, Patrick Hillery, was sworn in yesterday as the sixth President of the Irish Republic in a colorful ceremony at Dublin Castle.

NEWARK, Dec. 3 Most stores at North Jersey shopping malls in counties that prohibit Sunday sales will remain closed on the three remaining pre-Christmas Sundays despite the challenge by three major retail establishments of the constitutionality of a 1959 state law that limits Sunday sales, officials at four shopping centers and one in Passaic County said today.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 Some 3,500 landless peasants, who brought agricultural work to a standstill yesterday by occupying or threatening to occupy 106,000 acres of private farmland in the northwest Mexican state of Sinaloa, were persuaded to withdraw today, according to representatives of the landowners.

HARDENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 3 The residents of this small community in the Catskill Mountains who became ordained clergymen to protest rising property taxes are planning to take the final step toward tax exemption tomorrow by presenting formal applications to the Town Assessor.

For 23 years, Albert Rainaldi and his wife, Pasqualini, have owned and operated a small corner grocery a few miles east of downtown Pittsburgh. After all the years, they have come to regard their regular customers almost as part of the family.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Dec. 3 Kitty Carlisle Hart, the new chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, likened the arts to Blanche DuBois in "A Streetcar Named Desire" as "having always relied on the kindness of strangers."

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 3 A possible cracked patella in his right knee will keep Paul Smith, Fordham's starting center, out of tomorrow's basketball game with top-ranked Michigan. Smith has been the leading rebounder in both of the Rams' victories this season.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 3 (AP) A young gunman killed a traffic warden today at a school crossing in Dungannon, 40 miles west of Belfast, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today the recall of 170,000 transformers used to light the dials of "Princess" and "Trimline" telephones because they might overheat and catch fire.

The playful serenity of Sophie Maslow's choreography today gives no clue to the Sturm und Drang of her early experiences as a dancer. Her company presented a program of three works Thursday at the Theater of Riverside Church that were youthful in outlook with scarcely a hint of the darker forces that course through our experience.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP) A move by minority stockholders to block a proposed change in the ownership of the New England Patriots has been taken under advisement by a Federal judge.

GARFIELD, Dec. 3 A 15-year-old youth, shot two days ago by his ailing, 64-year-old father during a family quarrel, died today in St. Mary's Hospital in nearby Passaic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The national unemployment rate rose from 7.9 percent to 8.1 percent in November, its highest level this year, despite an apparent strong gain in the number of persons with jobs, the Labor Department reported today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3 Two apparent attempts to prevent a guilty verdict by trying to bribe one or more jurors in the political corruption trial of Gov. Martin Mandel of Maryland and four of his friends and business associates were confirmed today by the partial release of sealed court papers. Two men have been arrested; one of them was later released.

Johnny Majors, the 41-year-old coach who took the University of Pittsburgh football program to the top in just four years, has responded to the "lure of his homeland" and accepted the job as head coach and assistant athletic director at the University of Tennessee, his alma mater.

During the last deal of the last event in last week's fall nationals in Pittsburgh, one table suddenly became highly conspicuous. For reasons that were obscure to staring players from surrounding tables, Gail Moss of New York and Jeff Hand, an American now living in Panama City, Panama, were leaning back in their chairs and laughing uncontrollably.

A former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a retired New York banker were elected to the board of Gamble-Skogmo Inc. yesterday at a special meeting in Minneapolis in which another director resigned, the fifth to do so in a month.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3 Dr. Erwin Schwenk, former research director of the Schering Corporation of Bloomfield, N.J., and a contributor to early chemical research on steroid hormones, died Wednesday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 89 Years old and lived in Princeton.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 The St. Louis Cardinals tightened up the battle for playoff positions in the National Football League by a few more notches today when they defeated the Baltimore Colts, 24-17. Two of the key plays were defensive ones by the St. Louis team, better known for its offensive skills.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 Time again for the annual winter gathering of the baseball clans, and it couldn't have come at a worse time.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UPI) President Ford says he has had a lifelong ambition to be a professional baseball Player "but nobody would hire me." The President made the comment in a television interview taped Wednesday at the White House for broadcast today in a Marine Corps Reserve "Toys for Tots" telethon.

ROME, Dec. 5 Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti left for the United States today prepared to ask for financial help and to assure the incoming Carter Administration of his ability to deal with the economic crisis and the rising strength of the Communist Party.
NOWRA, Australia, Dec. 5 (AP) Fire in a hangar at the naval air station here early today virtually wiped out the Australian Navy's force of antisubmarine patrol planes.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) Benjamin Britten will be buried Tuesday near his home in the village of Aldeburgh, his publisher said today.

One of the delightful aspects of a very funny woman named Marcia Lewis, who appeared at Brothers and Sisters at 355 West 46th Street over the weekend, is that she is a singer and actress who can be serious or comic with equal effectiveness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 Five months after the Supreme Court upheld the death penalty as a permissible punishment for murder, the nation and the Court itself are entangled in new and rapidly increasing confusion and con troversy over the law on captial punishment.

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 5 (AP) -Jim Young was named today as head football coach at Purdue University. He succeeds Alex Agase, who was released two weeks ago. Terms of the contract were not announced, but it was reported that Young, who has been head coach at the University of Arizona for the last four years, received a five-year pact at $35,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The Codes Subcommittee of the Ethics Committee of the District of Columbia Bar has been asked to develop a set of rules to curb possible conflict of interest among lawyers who go into private practice here after working for the Government.

Terry Cashman, a pop producer, songwriter and singer who performed at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday, helped keep Brill Building music alive during the 1960's.

The 1976 search for the so-called Loch Ness monster has come to an end with results that were well, in a word-disappointing, but, the searchers hasten to add, not discouraging.
A twin-engine plane carrying five persons struck a radio tower in Forked River, N.J. Saturday night, sheared off its left wing and then crashed into a church, killing all aboard.

Roger Staubach picked the Philadelphia secondary apart with 22 pass completions in 30 attempts for 253 yards yesterday and contributed heavily to a 26-7. Dallas victory in Veterans Stadium, Philadelphia, that clinched the Cowboys' eighth National Football League Eastern Division title in the last 11 years.

Max Rosen, an 80-year-old greatgrandfather and retired house painter from the Brighton Beach Section of Brooklyn, and Heide Krueger, a 32-yearold model who lives on the East Side of Manhattan, would seem to have nothing in common.

LONDON, Dec. 5 Nothing comes easy for Britain's battered labor Government these days, but the week ahead will be particularly difficult. That is because it must try to satisfy two quite different audiences with the same piece of theater.

LOUISVILLE, Ky Bad news about the economy is not something a person out of work wants to hear. But, as Gregory L. Stepro signed up for unemployment compensation again last week, the Government was reporting an increase in the jobless rate to 8.1 percent in November.
Cocoa futures, whose record prices have been alarming many traders recently, declined a little most of last week and then jumped the daily limit again Friday.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 5 Cyrus R. vance the Secretary of State-designate, says that the Carter administration should give priority to concluding a new treaty with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms and to seeking an overall Middle East settlement but that it should not be rushed into establishing formal ties with Peking.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 6 Japan's governing Liberal-Democratic Party, faced with the most severe electoral test in its 21-year history, was on the verge today of losing its majority in the lower house of Parliament.

"Cry," now one of the bestknown pieces in the repertory of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, made its first appearance of the season at the City Center Saturday afternoon with Estelle Spurlock as its solo dancer.
The New York Rangers extended their unbeaten streak to eight games last night by tying the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-5.

A Long Island distributor has agreed to drop certain therapeutic claims for Russel Farms milk, a recently developed product for people unable to digest regular milk, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec.5 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it planned to update warnings on birth control pills taken by an estimated 8 million to 10 million American women to include new medical compli cations discovered since 1970.
PARIS. Dec. 5 Jacquer Chirac dissolved the Gaullist party today and transformed it into a new mass movement of personal support.
WASHINGTON,Dec.5 (AP) William E.Simon, the outgoing Treasury Secretary, says, in a magazine interview that if a simulus for the economy were needed he would urge a tax cut.

An estimated $250,000 worth of jewelry belonging to an oil company executive and his wife was stolen yesterday afternoon during a burglary of the couple's Fifth Avenue maisonette, the police reported.

HERAKLEION, Crete. Dec. 2-"Tourism is like very strong medicine," mused Mayor Manolis Karellis. "It can be very good for some things, but it can also have side effects. It has to be given very carefully, in measured doses."

NEWARK, Dec. 5 Newark police officers went Christmas shopping here today -to gather evidence for complaints against stores that were open or selling items in violation of so-called Blue Laws, which prohibit certain sales on Sundays.

BEIRUT, Lebanon. Dec. 5 President Elias Sarkis has extended the deadline for the collection of heavy weapons from rival Lebanese factions and Palestinian guerrillas, to avoid having to use force, while giving the opposing groups time to moderate their positions, according to informed sources here.
The whereabouts of Grace Garment remained unknown yesterday after a 13-state missing-person alarm was issued for the television writer and the wife of Leonard Garment.

"The Adventures of Jonathan Corncob, Loyal American," written by Himself, is one of the few surviving Revolutionary War novels. Television is nothing if not incredible or, if you will, ludicrous in its variety. Unusual additions to tonight's schedule include Mikhail Baryshnikov, Johnny Cash and something called "Feather and Father," a concoction that will soon become a regular weekly series.

If they finish with identical records, Washington is in because of two victories over St. Louis. So if Washington wins at Dallas next Sunday, Washington is in, no matter what St. Louis does against the Giants.

(AP) Walter Tresch of Switzerland beat Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden today in the final of the men's parallel slalom in the closing program of the World Series of Skiing. PRINCETON, N.J. The cool madness and hot sanity of August Strindberg have inspired a most unusual play that has just been given its American premiere at the McCarter Theater here. The play is "The Night of the Tribades," and it is written by the young Swedish writer Per Olov Enquist.

IF EVER there was a dish tailormade for quick cooking and pure enjoyment it is of the sort known in French as an emince, a word for which there is no exact English equivalent. An emince consists of any sort of meat cut into shreds and cooked quickly with liquids and seasonings added to make a sauce. Next to an omelet, perhaps, there are few dishes to be cooked in such a hurry.

"We're in bad shape, very bad shape we've done a lot of things we just can't continue to do," Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of the City University, said in describing the effects of the $135 million cut by the city from the university's last two budgets.

New York City financial officials, after a long struggle to conserve cash resources to pay ongoing expenses, disclosed yesterday that they expected a cash surplus of up to $300 million this year big enough to help redeem a significant portion of outstanding short-term notes as demanded by the State Court of Appeals.

This week, the Rapid-American Corporation won dismissal of an action by minority shareholders of Schenley Industries charging that Rapid-American issued false and misleading proxy information in connection with its 1971 acquisition of Schenley.

Willie Turnesa, youngest of seven brothers who have been fixtures in United States golf for more than 50 years, was honored yesterday for a lifetime of dedication to golf and related activities. Turnesa, winner of two United States Amateur championships and one British Amateur, received the Distinguished Service Award of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 8 An American effort to win final allied approval of a $2.44 billion airborne early-warning and control system ran into financial objections from hard-pressed European countries today and a decision was deferred until next year.

The Central Intelligence Agency's attempt in July 1974 to salvage a Soviet submarine failed when an error in judgment resulted in damage to prongs of a huge claw that was to have retrieved the submarine from a depth of three miles, according to two former members of the project.

KENT, Conn., Dec. 8 Charles Wilkins, a 51-year-old public-relations consultant, was held in $200,000 bail today at the kitchfield Correctional Center awaiting a hearing in Superior Court on charges of having murdered his wife and their 19year-old son.

LA FERTE-ST. AUBIN, France, Dec. 5 Gunshots cracked all over the French countryside this weekend as more than two million hunters took to the woods, bent on shooting for dinner or amusement virtually anything that rustled, loped or fluttered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The new campaign law permits a special interest political committee to give a Senate or a House candidate as much as $10,000 after he has won the election to help him retire campaign debts.

PEKING China's expanding but still backward economy relies to a considerable degree on manpower in industry and agriculture, on an industrious but unsophisticated labor force and on the utilization of raw materials of marginal value in advanced economies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 A proposal to put an extra $2 billion to $5 billion into subsidizing mortgages to aid the housing industry, and thereby the economy, will be one of the policy options placed before President-elect Jimmy Carter tomorrow by the economic experts on his transition staff.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 9 (Reuters) Two Ugandans were detained by British immigration officials at arrival at Heathrow Airport here yesterday, The Mail reported in today's issue.
A reporter for The New York Times has agreed to testify in the second murder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis that is now under way in Paterson, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 A proposal to put an extra $2 billion to $5 billion into subsidizing mortgages to aid the housing industry, and thereby the economy, will be one of the policy options placed before President-elect Jimmy Carter tomorrow by the economic experts on his transition staff.

Howard C. Kauffmann, president of the Exxon Corporation, detailed the company's previously reported $20 billion four-year capital and exploration spending program in a presentation to security analysts in Atlanta.

Aqueduct's stewards shortened the distance of yesterday's seventh and ninth races and moved both from the main track to the inner "winterized" one. The track's parimutuel department made refunds to fans on exacta and triple wagering prior to the two contests.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP) The American Bicentennial exhibit, a popular attraction here, was evacuated and closed for the day today after a telephoned bomb threat, but no bomb was found. It was the second such incident in three weeks.

AT HOME ABROAD "The Dutch Republic in the Days of John Adams, 1775 to 1795" is a new exhibition of art and artifacts from museums and private collectors in the Netherlands, organized by that country's government and circulated by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service. Centering on our second President's years as Ambassador to Holland, the Bicentennial show offers special interest for television viewers of "The Adams Chronicles."
Four Democratic members of Congress and the resident commissioner-elect of Puerto Rico announced yesterday the formation of the first Congressional Hispanic Caucus.
Maurice R. Brann, a retired independent oil producer and former Yale football star, died of a stroke Monday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 83 years old.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 8 (Reuters) Thailand today accused Vietnam of planning to invade Thailand on three fronts next February.

In a spirited rally from an early twogoal deficit, the New York Rangers tied the St. Louis Blues, 4-4, last night at the Garden on three goals by Wayne Dillon and a tying tally by Dave Farrish with about two minutes left in the middle period. Farrish's goal was the rookie defenseman's first in the National Hockey League.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 Abbots Laboratories of North Chicago, Ill., announced today that it had agreed to sell the Soviet Union its secret recipe for Similac, the baby formula. Under a contract worth more than $25 million. Abbott and the FMC Corporation of Chicago will design and equip ment factory in the Soviet Socialist Republic of Moldavia to produce 14,000 tons of Similac powder a year, enough to feed 1.5 million babies, according to Soviet officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Inquiries into questionable South Korean influence on Government policy widened today with the disclosure by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has been investigating possible bribes by a major defense contractor to Congressmen or other unidentified officials.

It is a neighborhood of one and two family wooden houses, worn by time, but kept up by solid, Jrish-American working people. Down the block is a side driveway into the parking lot of Salvi Ford.

Winston Paul, an industrialist and civic leader who was active in helping develop a new, and later revised, constitution for the State of New Jersey, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J., after a short illness. He lived in Montclair and was 89 years old.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 8 An American effort to win final allied approval of a $2.44 billion airborne early-warning and control system ran into financial objections from hard-pressed European countries today and a decision was deferred until next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) State and local governments across the country have filed nearly $24 billion world of applications for $2 billion that Congress made available for job-creating public works projects, officials reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Justice Department has officially closed its investigation of the Capitol Hill sex scandal in which former Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio was accused of putting his mistress on his Congressional payroll, a spokesman said today.

HARTFORD, Dec. 8?The leadership of the Connecticut State Senate called today for the naming of an independent special prosecutor to investigate the handling of the Peter Reilly murder case and prosecute state officials if improprieties are found.

Liggett Group Inc., of Durham, N.C., announced that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Tetley Inc., a Delaware corporation, owned by J. Lyons Company of London, for cash and assumption of debt aggregating $27 million.

Prices of gold and silver bullion futures bounded upward on New York and Chicago commodity exchanges yesterday in expectation of higher bids at the International Monetary Fund's latest auction of gold.

PATERSON. N.J., Dec. 8 The prosecution in the triple-murder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis rested its case today, the 23d day of the trial at the Passaic County Courthouse, having presented the testimony of 40 witnesses. some of them deceased.

How to restrain inflationary wage and price action is, as a great deal of economic history in the United States and other democracies has proved, an extremely difficult practical problem, not just a matter of ideology.

The book of the 1976 world team championships is the most complex of the series that has been produced annually by the American Contract Bridge League. It is now available for $5.95 from the league at 2200 Democrat Road, Memphis, Tenn., 38116, and gives full coverage of the Bermuda Bowl final in which the North American team beat the Italian Blue Team for the world title.

BANFF, Alberta, Dec. 7 Skimpy snow conditions, unusual even this early in the season for the Canadian Rockies, have drastically reduced the skiable terrain at the regular recreation areas. But operators of the helicopter oriented Canadian Mountain Holidays plan to open their season on schedule Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The Soviet Union will sell India 200 tons of heavy water for use in the Indian nuclear energy program, according to a submission to the International Atomic Energy Agency, United States officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Senior intelligence officials said today that Attorney General Edward H. Levi had refused to approve any requests for wiretaps in counterintelligence cases and that efforts to combat hostile foreign intelligence services were being hampered.

Jimmy Connors has won back his No. 1 ranking in the United States. Eddie Dibbs, the little Miami Beach star, advanced to second place; Harold Solomon received the No. 4 spot, and Brian Gottfried was placed fifth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board acted too hastily in rejecting an application for regularly scheduled, coast-to-coast airline service by World Airways that would cost $89 for a one-way ticket, a Federal appellate court ruled today.

ANKARA, Turkey. Dec. 8-The snows of winter are starting to sweep across eastern Turkey, and government officials face an extremely difficult job in providing shelter for more than 50,000 people left homeless by the earthquake that devastated the region almost two weeks ago.

A mass of the resurrection will be offered today for Barbara Barnes Godfrey, a community and civic leader in Suffolk County, at SS. Phillip and James Roman Catholic Church in St. James, L.I. Mrs, Godfrey died Sunday at her home in St. James after a brief illness. She was 42 years old.

Dr. John J. Bottone, an attending urologist on the staff at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn since 1932, died Tuesday in the hospital of heart disease. He lived at 19 Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn and was 72 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 George Scott, who was all set to go home again, may not get there after all.

The Knicks' pursuit of Bob McAdoo has evidently ended in failure. After six days of negotiations between Mike Burke and Paul Snyder and after three separate oral agreements between the two on the trade that was to have brought the Buffalo Braves' sharpshooter to the Knicks Burke is now convinced that the deal is off.

Bob Blackman's return to the Ivy League as the new head football coach at Cornell is seen as beneficial for the league by other Ivy coaches, who also view his return as a definite challenge.

A Queens grand jury, which has handed up indictments against 54 persons, charging that they defrauded the city of hundreds of thousands of dollars of welfare funds, has recommended two major changes in the current welfare payment system that the jury said encourages cheating.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Dec. 8 (AP) Dr. Earl King Gil, who originated the "12th man" tradition at Texas A. M. University, died last night at his Rockport home of a possible heart attack. He was 74 years old.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 8 (AP) Three members of the Pittston School Board were sentenced today to six months in jail and fined $3,000 each for extortion.

The New York Cultural Center of Columbus Circle, empty since fiscal troubles closed it in September 1975, has been bought by Gulf Western Industries as a gift to New York City. It will serve as headquarters for the new Department of Cultural Affairs and as an exhibition and tourist center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency reported today substantial improvements in air quality as a result of Federal regulation over a five-year period ending in 1975.

Older heads have prevailed in forging at least a temporary truce in the bitter dispute between the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service over the issue of which organization controls national programming for public television.

John Horvath, a senior planner at the McCann-Erickson advertising agency, died Monday at his home at 65-30 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 52 years old.

Members of the United States Commission for UNESCO said yesterday that unless Americans helped third-world countries in training journalists and developing modern communications systems, these nations would tighten government control over the news media.
DETROIT, Dec. 8 American car production is scheduled to reach a yearly high of 207,656 units this week even though production is cut back at three plants, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

W.R. Grace Company announced an agreement in principle to acquire Channel Companies Inc., a specialty retailer of home improvements, for about $19.4 million.

ATLANTA The Era of Good Feelings, a phrase coined in 1817 by The Columbian Centinel to describe the one-party euphoria of the James Monroe Administration, turned out to be a time marked by petty factionalism and stagnation. Not until party partisanship reared its divisive head, under the banner of Andrew Jackson, did a vigorous two-party system get the nation moving again.

United States imports of foreign oil rose to their highest level on record last week as oil companies stocked up in anticipation of a price increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 Most of the country's large corporations appear to be planning to offer more jobs to college graduates next year than they did last June.

VAL d'ISERE, France, Dec. 9 Abbi Fisher, a very competitive skier from South Conway, N.H., finished second today in the opening action of the world Cup, a giant slalom. She was 19 one-hundredths of a second behind Lise-Marie Morerod of Switzerland, the winner of seven World Cup races last season, and 19 one-hundredths of a second ahead of Annemarie Proell-Moser of Austria, the titleholder for five successive years on skiing's only major league circuit.

Cathy Chamberlain, who has studied opera, engineering and fashion design, has been a go-go dancer and who has mastered two musical instruments the jug and the concertina has finally found a mission in life. She wants to pay homage to the American music heritage.
The CBS Foundation has made a $1 million grant to the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism to establish a chair in international Journalism.

PARIS, Dec. 9 The north-south conference of rich and poor countries, scheduled to open here next week to continue negotiations toward a new world economic order, has been postponed, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The Federal Reserve Board gave conditional approval today to applications by four states, including New York, to be exempted from provisions of Federal anti-redlining legislation because they have "substantially similar laws."
THE MEDUSA and Tutankhamen images fashioned by the jewelers and craftsmen of the early 20th century, represent brisk business these days to at least four Madison Avenue shops.
NEWARK, Dec. 9 Eighteen persons three of them juveniles, were charged today by the Newark Police Department with stealing and cashing $45,000 in checks intended for summer youth workers.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 A Federal judge cleared the way today for Ohio's 25 Presidential electors to vote for Jimmy Carter when the Electoral College meets Monday.
Rutgers and Kansas both came back from first-half deficits and scored impressive victories last night as Madison Square Garden opened its 43d season of college basketball before a crowd of 7,678.

The Singer Company announced yesterday that it had decided to get out of the mailing equipment, knitting, putting, venture-capital and traffic-control businesses. Provisions totaling $52.3 million were established for expenses and possible were established for actions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9 Arab and Western countries reached a compromise today on a proposal for an international treaty against the taking of hostages. The agreement virtually assures unanimous adoption of the resolution by the General Assembly's Legal Committee.
TEL AVIV, Dec 9 Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon, the hero of the war of 1973 who organized a new party for the Israeli parliamentary elections in November, made public a program for Middle East peace today.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Dec. 9 Dr. Simon J. Molnar, 58 years old, director of athletics at the State University College here, died late last night, apparently of a heart attack.

FIFTH AVENUE, a window-shopper's winter wonderland in holiday trappings as festive as a Christmas tree candy cane, will hold an open house for all of New York this Sunday when motor traffic will be removed to make way for pedestrian frolics.

UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP) Patricia Bolin, a 40-year-old mother of three, used a 22-caliber gun to kill her husband and two of her children before shooting herself to death, the police said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) The Navy suffered its highest desertion rate on record during the 1976 fiscal year and Navy officials say they do not know why.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Dec. 10 (AP) Lou Holtz arrived today at the University of Arkansas to discuss becoming the next head football coach of the Razorbacks.
ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP) Roland Ericksson scored with 4 minutes 38 seconds to play, enabling the Minnesota North Stars to tie the Atlanta Flames, 3-3, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

There are not many things on which the world agrees, but everyone I think acknowledges the importance of a Nobel Prize. I myself take most seriously the Nobel Committee's recognition of the highest excellence in several fields, and I accept the honor of this award with profound gratitude.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 10 Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic P. Byrne were acquitted today of charges of kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d in August 1975, but were convicted of grand larceny for extorting a $2.3 million ransom from Mr. Bronfman's father, Edgar, who is chairman of the Seagram Company Ltd.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 Presidentelect Jimmy Carter has selected the team of persons for the top national security positions in his Administration but is still sorting out which candidate will fill which job, a top aide said today.

The International Harvester Company said yesterday that an investigation by the audit committee of its board had disclosed that one foreign subsidiary paid improper commissions amounting to $273,000 between 1972 and 1975 and that certain foreign units overcharged certain foreign customers by about $5 million over the last five years.
Alden H. MacIntyre, a retired Boston banker and a direct descendant of John Alden of the Mayflower settlers in Plymouth, Mass., died Thursday in his home in Cambridge, Mass. His age was 77.
"Let the TV go first;" a publicity man was shouting as camera crews dragged cables and lights across an orange carpet toward Bob McAdoo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 Presidentelect Jimmy Carter said today that his "first priority" in stimulating the economy would be to channel Government money into programs to create jobs and that any tax reduction he proposed would be a supplement to that effort.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10 John W. Barriger 3d, former president of the Missouri, Kansas, Texas Railroad and once a top executive of seven other railroads, died here yesterday after surgery. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The Environmental Protection Agency ordered the Chrysler Corporation today to recall 208,000 of its 1975 model automobiles because of what the agency said were faulty design and maintenance problem producing excessive air pollution.

Donald McKayle's latest dance, "Blood Memories," which had its world premiere at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Thursday night, is ambitious, exciting and long. It is one of the longest ballets the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has ever produced, lasting about 50 minutes. Its scope and its range are also considerable.
The police commander of the Chinatown precinct was transferred to administrative duties to make way "for a tougher cop," a high-ranking police official said yesterday.

A top official of the International Longshoremen's Association was indicted yesterday on Federal charges of accepting nearly $90,000 in cash payments from the United Brands Company when the company's cargo was tied up in longshoremen's strikes in 1968-69 and 1971.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 10 (UPI) A State Police observer was ordered today to look into the dispute between Mayor Edward Hanna and local police officials that led to the Mayor's arrest and the so-far ignored suspensions of the Police Chief and three other officers.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 10 While efforts to resolve the Rhodesian dispute grind on inconclusively in Geneva, a less publicized dispute with many of the same elements a guerrilla war, an entrenched white minority and a faction-ridden black majority smolders on in the huge, mineral-rich territory of South-West Africa.
WEST POINT, N.Y. Dec. 10 The Corps of Cadets has voted to retain expulsion as the single and automatic penalty for violation of the honor code of the United States Military Academy here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 The General Assembly tonight approved a treaty that aims at outlawing the manipulation of the environment for military or hostile purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 A Justice Department report made public today finds that small oil refiners "have shied away" from participation in two proposed Gulf of Mexico offshore oil ports because of financing arrangements devised by the big oil companies that control the ventures.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 10 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger made a farewell appeal to America's allies today to maintain strong defenses while pursuing mutual restraint with the Russians to avoid "an unimaginable catastrophe."

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 8 Life had fled the place, but life's traces remained: a red sweater, left behind by its tiny owner. A sign imploring, "Come out of your shell! Read!" Untouched crayons and unopened pencil boxes. A lost cap and an unmatched glove tacked up on a bulletin board. Chairs built for small frames, empty now and piled on unused desks.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 The Soviet Union today joined a growing list of countries in extending the offshore fishing limit to 200 nautical miles.

HARWICHPORT, Mass., Dec. 10 (AP) Dudley Harmon, a former newspaperman who began crusading 50 years ago for joint action by New England states on their common problems, died Wednesday at his home here after several months' illness. He was 90 years old. Private services were held yesterday at his home.

When they calculate this year's profits and losses, some investors will have squeezed sizable capital gains out of two unlikely sources Penn Central and Boston Maine railroad bonds.

ANGERS, France Young women from six countries talked freely recently about some things their mothers would have only whispered about.

Why does the New York subway have such a bad press? It is dirty, yes, but not nearly so dirty as the typical Manhattan residential street happily tenanted by New Yorkers complaining about dirt in the subway. This alone should qualify it as one of the more hygienic sanctuaries in town.

Crawford, 25 years old, of Camden, N.J., was arrested in Hawaii yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the slaying earlier this year of Betty Jo Mosely of Camden. The F.B.I. had been searching for him since last March 28 under a fugitive warrant.

If last week's sudden jolt of frigid weather was not enough to convince gardeners that rough times are ahead for plants, then take a look at the rhododendrons. On cold frosty mornings, their leaves are curled up into tiny cigarlike strips. Just looking at them is enough to make anyone shiver. Pachysandra does the same thing.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11--Yale squads defeated Columbia in swimming and track today. The Eli trackmen won, 6652, as Harry Davis, a junior, captured three events--the 60-yard high hurdles, 60-yard dash and the long jump. Charles Allen, a Columbia sophomore, took the high jump at 6 feet 10 inches.

From Pisa I went south to Tarquinia to see the painted tombs of the Etruscans, a trip of three hours down the west, coast of Italy alongside the Tyrrhenian Sea. It was a Sunday train, lazy and half empty, stopping often as we went deeper and deeper into the Tuscan sun. Sunflowers stood high in the fields. Tawny houses flashed by the window, houses made of golden bales of summer hay.
KANSAS CITY, Dec., 11 (AP)--The Kansas City Chiefs have chosen Gary Barbaro, a safety, as their rookie of the year and Mike Livingston, quarterback, as their most valuable player.

Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Roy of Port Chester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Suc Roy, to Anthony David Elias, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julius Elias of Storrs, Conn. The future bride and her fiance, cum laude graduates of Princeton University, attend the New York University School of Medicine. A June wedding is planned.

Administrators of colleges around the state appeared at a state legislative hearing and charged that both students and colleges have suffered because of delays in receiving grants under the state's Tuition Assistance Program.

UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio, Dec. 11 (AP)--A 40-year-old woman who killed three members of her family before fatally shooting herself was buried with them today, Patricia Bolin shot her husband, Ronald, 43 years old, and two of her three children, Todd, 9, and Tamela, 12, Wednesday night, the police said. A third child was spared when Mrs. Bolin ran out of ammunition. The police said that they did not find a motive.

They are so impatient to turn pro that they don't even try to earn a diploma.

WEST MILFORD, N.J., Dec. 10 (AP)-- Joseph Schott, 15 years old, of West Milford, who was hunting deer in a wooded area off Clinton Road here, was killed yesterday when a shotgun accidentally fired after it fell to the ground, the police said. After the accident, the youth's hunting companion, a 15-year-old whose name was not released, ran one and a quarter miles to the nearest house to summon help, the police said.

GENEVA--The Socialist International, descended directly from Karl Marx's first organization, heard from a number of prime ministers and presidents at its congress here last month. Oric Bovar, a 59-year-old mystic who led a two-month-long prayer vigil in an effort to bring a dead follower back to life, has been described by a number of former adherents in New York City and in Los Angeles as a one-time astrologer whose powers of persuasion convinced as many as 200 followers, including wellknown show business personalities, that he was Jesus Christ.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11--After five days of continual meetings and occasional name-calling, the people who run baseball went home today and added up the score: Fewer trades were made than at any time in the last five years and no teams were relocated yet to solve the sport's urgent problems in geography and politics.

NEW JERSEY has lost 142,000 manufacturing jobs in the last 10 years, with the big decline --88,000 jobs-having occurred since 1974. The loss since 1966 amounts to one of every six manufacturing jobs in the state.
